subject: Use a static inventory skeleton
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2799, 'name': 'Andy McCrae', 'email': 'andy.mccrae@googlemail.com', 'username': 'andrew-mccrae'}, {'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24468, 'name': 'Limestone Networks CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci@limestonenetworks.com', 'username': 'limestone-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25023, 'name': 'Jonathan Rosser', 'email': 'jonathan.rosser@rd.bbc.co.uk', 'username': 'jrosser'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-05 12:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-06 12:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-06 12:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 14:13:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm +2 on this as I have a need for this at work however I'd prefer the static inventory to be yaml. It's easier to read, machine readable, and extendable without needing to use much more than the python standard library."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-11 15:59:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I find this very readable, and this format is very well known in the Ansible community so it would be easy for everyone to understand. I'm not sure I understand why it needs to be yaml given that Ansible can read multiple inventories, so any extensions required can be done using yaml or whatever else in user-space. That said, Kevin, it might be nice to see a patch on top of this which expresses the inventory in yaml format to make comparison easier.

I also find myself wondering whether this covers all the bases. Is there a reason we're not yet removing the env.d file in this patch too?"}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 17:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> I find this very readable, and this format is very well known in
> the Ansible community so it would be easy for everyone to
> understand. I'm not sure I understand why it needs to be yaml given
> that Ansible can read multiple inventories, so any extensions
> required can be done using yaml or whatever else in user-space.

While I agree that extending the inventory should exist in userspace, I have an issue with basic INI based inventory making it difficult to read programically. If the inventory is JSON or YAML I can use almost any off the shelf tool to read and react accordingly.

> That said, Kevin, it might be nice to see a patch on top of this
> which expresses the inventory in yaml format to make comparison
> easier.

I've converted the inventory from INI to YAML and that can be found here: [ http://paste.openstack.org/show/725591 ]. In that inventory you'll notice that it's smaller, covers the same groups, has all of the same comments, and is machine readable using basic tools/languages. In that example you'll also notice I corrected several of the consistent names issues we've had, namely for: [haproxy, memcached, hosts, elasticsearch, kibana, logstash, rsyslog, unbound]. Additionally there's an internal group which ansible assumes is present called "ungrouped" which i've included for completeness.

> I also find myself wondering whether this covers all the bases. Is
> there a reason we're not yet removing the env.d file in this patch
> too?

+1 I think it'd be great to roll in all of the env.d bits into a static inventory base, if possible.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-12 11:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > I find this very readable, and this format is very well known in
 > > the Ansible community so it would be easy for everyone to
 > > understand. I'm not sure I understand why it needs to be yaml
 > given
 > > that Ansible can read multiple inventories, so any extensions
 > > required can be done using yaml or whatever else in user-space.
 > 
 > While I agree that extending the inventory should exist in
 > userspace, I have an issue with basic INI based inventory making it
 > difficult to read programically. If the inventory is JSON or YAML I
 > can use almost any off the shelf tool to read and react
 > accordingly.
 > 
 > > That said, Kevin, it might be nice to see a patch on top of this
 > > which expresses the inventory in yaml format to make comparison
 > > easier.
 > 
 > I've converted the inventory from INI to YAML and that can be found
 > here: [ http://paste.openstack.org/show/725591 ]. In that inventory
 > you'll notice that it's smaller, covers the same groups, has all of
 > the same comments, and is machine readable using basic
 > tools/languages. In that example you'll also notice I corrected
 > several of the consistent names issues we've had, namely for:
 > [haproxy, memcached, hosts, elasticsearch, kibana, logstash,
 > rsyslog, unbound]. Additionally there's an internal group which
 > ansible assumes is present called "ungrouped" which i've included
 > for completeness.
 > 
 > > I also find myself wondering whether this covers all the bases.
 > Is
 > > there a reason we're not yet removing the env.d file in this
 > patch
 > > too?
 > 
 > +1 I think it'd be great to roll in all of the env.d bits into a
 > static inventory base, if possible.

I think there is confusion there.

1) This is not meant to be read programatically. Why would you need that?
2) If you really want to read programatically, ansible-inventory can convert it to json. However, INI files are not hard to manipulate either. See config_template.
3) The ansible inventory your are linking to is not smaller. It has groups that, IMO, should not appear.

Example:

haproxy_all:
  haproxy: {}

or:

memcached_all:
  children:
    memcached: {}

4) It is not meant for user space. These are the groups necessary to deploy an openstack cloud. This is setting a convention. The users can then use their own inventory in user space, to fill in the groups. I strongly advise them to use YAML for ease of use and avoid repetitions.

5) This patch is NOT meant to cover all the bases and become a mega patch.
Instead, it explains the structure required for a deployment, structure that can easily be modified by humans. No need to change env.d anymore and risk issues with deployments.

6) This patch is the base for the rest of the inventory spec. Please have a look at it.
We clearly define the context of what's required. If we do this, deployers can come with their own inventory system.

7) Kevin, your patch is incomplete: It's not because you edit the inventory to be with a new groupname that it will automagically works. That's why this patch is part of a series.
There is no reason to keep something like "memcached_all" or "haproxy_all", so that's what I am tackling in other patches. And to fix the wiring it would be simply editing a .ini file.

I think it's fair to say this will be more readable by humans at the end.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-12 15:37:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > > I find this very readable, and this format is very well known
 > in
 > > > the Ansible community so it would be easy for everyone to
 > > > understand. I'm not sure I understand why it needs to be yaml
 > > given
 > > > that Ansible can read multiple inventories, so any extensions
 > > > required can be done using yaml or whatever else in user-space.
 > >
 > > While I agree that extending the inventory should exist in
 > > userspace, I have an issue with basic INI based inventory making
 > it
 > > difficult to read programically. If the inventory is JSON or YAML
 > I
 > > can use almost any off the shelf tool to read and react
 > > accordingly.
 > >
 > > > That said, Kevin, it might be nice to see a patch on top of
 > this
 > > > which expresses the inventory in yaml format to make comparison
 > > > easier.
 > >
 > > I've converted the inventory from INI to YAML and that can be
 > found
 > > here: [ http://paste.openstack.org/show/725591 ]. In that
 > inventory
 > > you'll notice that it's smaller, covers the same groups, has all
 > of
 > > the same comments, and is machine readable using basic
 > > tools/languages. In that example you'll also notice I corrected
 > > several of the consistent names issues we've had, namely for:
 > > [haproxy, memcached, hosts, elasticsearch, kibana, logstash,
 > > rsyslog, unbound]. Additionally there's an internal group which
 > > ansible assumes is present called "ungrouped" which i've included
 > > for completeness.
 > >
 > > > I also find myself wondering whether this covers all the bases.
 > > Is
 > > > there a reason we're not yet removing the env.d file in this
 > > patch
 > > > too?
 > >
 > > +1 I think it'd be great to roll in all of the env.d bits into a
 > > static inventory base, if possible.
 > 
 > I think there is confusion there.
 > 
 > 1) This is not meant to be read programatically. Why would you need
 > that?

Given the fact that there is a way to read this programatically, without any additional overhead, why would you not want that?

 > 2) If you really want to read programatically, ansible-inventory
 > can convert it to json. 

While true, you could just write it in YAML and there's no need to convert it. Additionally, as noted in a different patch the ansible-inventory converter has several dire consequences with it as it pulls in group and host variables and could significantly modify the structure, see [ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/581568/ ] for more on that.

 > However, INI files are not hard to manipulate either. See config_template.

While the premise is true, the context is not. The ansible inventory format in INI does not actually ad-hear to the INI specifications so it is quite difficult to manipulate; traditional Ansible inventories are more TOML than they are INI. On an aside, I wrote `config_template` so I'm well aware of what it is.

 > 3) The ansible inventory your are linking to is not smaller. It has
 > groups that, IMO, should not appear.
 > 
 > Example:
 > 
 > haproxy_all:
 > haproxy: {}
 > 
 > or:
 > 
 > memcached_all:
 > children:
 > memcached: {}
 > 

As my previous comment states, I added them for reference to fix consistency issues. However we could quite easily remove them to make it a 1:1 to the INI. and the YAML inventory is in fact smaller especially if you just look at line count alone.

 > 4) It is not meant for user space. These are the groups necessary
 > to deploy an openstack cloud. This is setting a convention. The
 > users can then use their own inventory in user space, to fill in
 > the groups. I strongly advise them to use YAML for ease of use and
 > avoid repetitions.

I'm not asking for this to be user-space, I'm asking for it to be machine readable.

 > 5) This patch is NOT meant to cover all the bases and become a mega
 > patch.
 > Instead, it explains the structure required for a deployment,
 > structure that can easily be modified by humans. No need to change
 > env.d anymore and risk issues with deployments.

+1 sounds good.

 > 6) This patch is the base for the rest of the inventory spec.
 > Please have a look at it.
 > We clearly define the context of what's required. If we do this,
 > deployers can come with their own inventory system.
 > 
 > 7) Kevin, your patch is incomplete: It's not because you edit the
 > inventory to be with a new groupname that it will automagically
 > works. 

I didn't link to a patch however if you have a look at [ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/581568/ ] you can see that a straight conversion of our dynamic inventory works in static YAML format.

 > That's why this patch is part of a series.
 > There is no reason to keep something like "memcached_all" or
 > "haproxy_all", so that's what I am tackling in other patches. And
 > to fix the wiring it would be simply editing a .ini file. 

I'm not advocating for us to keep those groups or for us to use them. My example was in response to Jesse asking for a the INI inventory to be written in YAML for comparison which I did, and noted that I extended to correct consistency issues. To that end, in this patch, regardless of INI or YAML format, we should also remove the ELK related groups as they have no barring on OpenStack and "There is no reason to keep something like" them.

 > I think it's fair to say this will be more readable by humans at
 > the end.

I agree this will be more readable, and I believe it will be EVEN MORE readable in YAML format, for both machines and humans, especially if we add variables or any other complexities to the base skeleton in the future.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-17 12:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > 1) This is not meant to be read programatically. Why would you

 > > that?

Because that's less readable/explicit for newcomers.

 > 
 > > 2) If you really want to read programatically, ansible-inventory
 > > can convert it to json.
 > 
 > While true, you could just write it in YAML and there's no need to
 > convert it. Additionally, as noted in a different patch the
 > ansible-inventory converter has several dire consequences with it
 > as it pulls in group and host variables and could significantly
 > modify the structure, see [ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/581568/
 > ] for more on that.

The idea is to modify the group structure in the long term to
clean the technical debt.

 > 
 > > However, INI files are not hard to manipulate either. See
 > config_template.
 > 
 > While the premise is true, the context is not. The ansible
 > inventory format in INI does not actually ad-hear to the INI
 > specifications so it is quite difficult to manipulate; traditional
 > Ansible inventories are more TOML than they are INI. On an aside, I
 > wrote `config_template` so I'm well aware of what it is.
 > 
 > > 3) The ansible inventory your are linking to is not smaller. It
 > has
 > > groups that, IMO, should not appear.
 > >
 > > Example:
 > >
 > > haproxy_all:
 > > haproxy: {}
 > >
 > > or:
 > >
 > > memcached_all:
 > > children:
 > > memcached: {}
 > >
 > 
 > As my previous comment states, I added them for reference to fix
 > consistency issues. However we could quite easily remove them to
 > make it a 1:1 to the INI. and the YAML inventory is in fact smaller
 > especially if you just look at line count alone.

Please try on a production inventory.
In most of my attempts in the past, YAML was always longer.

However, yes, in this case of a skeleton inventory, YAML would be shorter,
as there is no repetitions of the group names.

On top of this you're abusing of the notation to define a group.
groupname: {}

Hopefully this works for the current version of ansible (and probably some older versions too).
However this was never documented to work:

The json of a group should be:

groupname:
  children:
    groupname
  hosts:
    hostname
  vars:
    variablename

where each of the dicts children/hosts/vars are optional, but the group definition wasn't meant to be an empty dict.
Neither was the idea to auto build a group from its children definition (try with the ini to NOT define the child groups of [parentgroup:children])

On top of that, I find it less readable to have groupname: {} than just [groupname]. And it's less characters, as this matters to you :p


 > 
 > > 4) It is not meant for user space. These are the groups necessary
 > > to deploy an openstack cloud. This is setting a convention. The
 > > users can then use their own inventory in user space, to fill in
 > > the groups. I strongly advise them to use YAML for ease of use
 > and
 > > avoid repetitions.
 > 
 > I'm not asking for this to be user-space, I'm asking for it to be
 > machine readable.

WHY? That's the most important part for me to understand why you are voting negatively? I don't understand this.
Ansible reads it just fine.

 > 
 > > 5) This patch is NOT meant to cover all the bases and become a
 > mega
 > > patch.
 > > Instead, it explains the structure required for a deployment,
 > > structure that can easily be modified by humans. No need to

 > I didn't link to a patch however if you have a look at [
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/581568/ ] you can see that a
 > straight conversion of our dynamic inventory works in static YAML
 > format.
 > 
 > > That's why this patch is part of a series.
 > > There is no reason to keep something like "memcached_all" or
 > > "haproxy_all", so that's what I am tackling in other patches. And
 > > to fix the wiring it would be simply editing a .ini file.
 > 
 > I'm not advocating for us to keep those groups or for us to use
 > them. My example was in response to Jesse asking for a the INI
 > inventory to be written in YAML for comparison which I did, and
 > noted that I extended to correct consistency issues. To that end,
 > in this patch, regardless of INI or YAML format, we should also
 > remove the ELK related groups as they have no barring on OpenStack
 > and "There is no reason to keep something like" them.
 > 
 > > I think it's fair to say this will be more readable by humans at

 > 
 > I agree this will be more readable, and I believe it will be EVEN
 > MORE readable in YAML format, for both machines and humans,
 > especially if we add variables or any other complexities to the
 > base skeleton in the future.

I don't think we should add variables and complexities in this.
Variables belong to group/host vars, which we already have statically defined.
Complexities should not be here.



---

Could you explain why there is a problem with INI? I have the impression we are heading to a war over INI vs YAML, and I don't see the point of this war.
Ansible users, whether they are long time users or not, are taught to deal with INI inventory files. I think it makes sense to write with what they are used to see, else
we are exposing ourselves to questions like "what does groupname: {} do?".'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-25 09:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Use a static inventory skeleton

This provides a default static inventory, to complement the
current dynamic inventory.

It provides the ability to staticly define groups and their
hierarchy in an easier way than the dynamic inventory.

It can also be used as a basis for deployers to use their
own inventory in /etc/openstack_deploy/inventory.ini.

Change-Id: If9672e3a5794c36b7735ec3d34dc93f5bf79504b

[{'created': '2018-07-26 09:01:49.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I05126460d1711db73778775d5c1e83fd2e8bcb9d
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I05126460d1711db73778775d5c1e83fd2e8bcb9d

commit_message:
WIP - Adds new bootstrap-subnodes role instead of tripleo.sh

This role is intended to replace invocation of tripleo.sh
--bootstrap-subnodes from ci jobs.

more context @ https://trello.com/c/GvjcnJB2/850-translate-tripleosh-bootstrap-into-a-series-of-tasks

Change-Id: If881b74c6bee82b57a124639221ccb1477303326

[{'created': '2018-07-06 07:17:13.000000000', 'message': "Modify operator image workflow specs

Modified specs to reflect changes as per the implementation.
Highlights:
If 'hidden' column is not present in the databse then image-update
call will be rejected with 409 Conflict.
If image-update call to update 'hidden' field is made on image having
status other than 'active', it will be considered as 400 Bad Request.

Change-Id: I9d012a81ad5c8d209cf52634740268989eaed928
"}, {'created': '2018-07-19 17:10:30.000000000', 'message': "Modify operator image workflow specs

Modified specs to reflect changes as per the implementation.
Highlights:
In the response of create/show image the new property will be
displayed as 'os_hidden'.
If a pre-Rocky image already has a custom property named as
'os_hidden' then that property will no longer be visible in
the response from Rocky release.

Change-Id: I9d012a81ad5c8d209cf52634740268989eaed928

commit_message:
Modify operator image workflow specs

Modified specs to reflect changes as per the implementation.
Highlights:
In the response of create/show image the new property will be
displayed as 'os_hidden'.
If a pre-Rocky image already has a custom property named as
'os_hidden' then that property will no longer be visible in
the response from Rocky release.

Change-Id: I9d012a81ad5c8d209cf52634740268989eaed928

I haven't, but the line that is causing the error has if python > 3.5 throw an error, so I am pretty sure it won't work in py37 either"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-19 18:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-07-19 18:51:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-19 21:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-19 21:20:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://pypi.org/project/zVMCloudConnector/
we already have 1.2.2 out, so the bug should already been fixed
guess no need to work on requirements stuff?'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-07-20 02:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

1.2.2 should be part of the next reqs bump (tonight)'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-07-20 02:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:10:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

The fix is going to be OK for py36 but will break again when we start doing py37 work. Not sure if we want to preempt that issue, or wait for it to fail again?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Maybe just blacklist the version(s) with problems?'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:18:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

the problem is with all versions - https://github.com/mfcloud/python-zvm-sdk/blob/master/zvmsdk/version.py#L28-L29'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-07-22 06:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

bot update included 1.2.2, which includes the 3.6 fix  probably best to clse this I think'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-22 12:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-22 12:57:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> bot update included 1.2.2

For reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583867/4/upper-constraints.txt@144'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-07-23 03:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> the problem is with all versions - https://github.com/mfcloud/python-zvm-sdk/blob/master/zvmsdk/version.py#L28-L29

https://review.gerrithub.io/c/mfcloud/python-zvm-sdk/+/419929

FYI, we realized this issue and we already removed this check'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-07-24 15:10:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

so time to abandon?'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-24 15:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> so time to abandon?

+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-26 14:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Looks like it is all sorted now - abandoning'}]

commit_message:
Do not install zVMCloudConnector in py36+

Currently if this is installed it raises an error on
install: http://paste.openstack.org/show/726284/

Related-Bug: #1782604

Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

subject: fix tox python3 overrides
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-21 08:52:35.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ifbfe3a3ff1d027e5188d8131e1165363adc5275a
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ifbfe3a3ff1d027e5188d8131e1165363adc5275a

fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that

subject: fix tox python3 overrides
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-21 08:00:55.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I78a2bbbbab3991f8a12e9cb60a072557074611a3
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I78a2bbbbab3991f8a12e9cb60a072557074611a3

commit_message:
Fix GPT bug with whole disk images

Whole disk images with GPT partition tables would encounter
errors after the initial deploy as secondary copy of the
GPT partition table did not match the first table. This is
something we explicitly need to act upon for ironic.

Original commit message:

As suggested by TheJulia, the `_fix_gpt_structs` code
which is currently not accessible/callable from outside of ironic-lib
should be exposed so that other code like ironic-python-agent
can use it such as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568524/

Continuation of backport commit message:

To enable backporting of this patch such that we can address
the bug that it fixes in older releases, the method has been
preserved as a hidden method with a leading underscore.

Change-Id: Icd824982d23966605fb179270bbf428cab23a41d
(cherry picked from commit e4f16012d98907c76e0994a0999c3332c41c8ead)

commit_message:
zun: rename NETWORK to NETWORK_ID

This is for addressing outstanding comments in
I4b8c0257b83e97444dd8ff6ce88e240d12278ec2 . The name NETWORK_ID
is picked by the ServerMixin class so we rename it.

Change-Id: I1494af1af0c47337e746b449838f4519df06dac6

commit_message:
Fix GPT bug with whole disk images

Whole disk images with GPT partition tables would encounter
errors after the initial deploy as secondary copy of the
GPT partition table did not match the first table. This is
something we explicitly need to act upon for ironic.

Original commit message:

As suggested by TheJulia, the `_fix_gpt_structs` code
which is currently not accessible/callable from outside of ironic-lib
should be exposed so that other code like ironic-python-agent
can use it such as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568524/

Continuation of backport commit message:

To enable backporting of this patch such that we can address
the bug that it fixes in older releases, the method has been
preserved as a hidden method with a leading underscore.

Change-Id: Icd824982d23966605fb179270bbf428cab23a41d
(cherry picked from commit e4f16012d98907c76e0994a0999c3332c41c8ead)

messages:
[{'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-03 08:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-12 12:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I think it would be good to land this in stable branches so we prevent people from encountering issues... It is missing a reno, we could post one I guess?'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-07-14 00:50:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 Workflow+1

Thanks!

Although... if we backport this, it will only get used if we push out a release, then update eg ironic stable/queens to use this version, right?

So the patch looks good; I'm just not sure why we want to backport this."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-07-14 00:51:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-07-14 00:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

Sorry, I accidentally hit the +A, and forgot how to cancel it.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-07-14 17:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Putting -2 to make sure we discuss it, please ping me on Monday. This is a feature, so we should be careful in backporting it. But more importantly, using it in Ironic/IPA/anything will require bumping requirements, which is not acceptable on a stable branch. A potential path forward may be using this function conditionally, falling back to something else if it's not present. I suggest we discuss with the stable team."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-15 13:23:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Putting -2 to make sure we discuss it, please ping me on Monday.
 > This is a feature, so we should be careful in backporting it. But
 > more importantly, using it in Ironic/IPA/anything will require
 > bumping requirements, which is not acceptable on a stable branch. A
 > potential path forward may be using this function conditionally,
 > falling back to something else if it's not present. I suggest we
 > discuss with the stable team.

I would classify it a bug fix that morphed into exposure of an internal method which in a sense does make it a features... yet it would be good to fix the behavior. We could always update the backports to be a hidden method so then it is purely still considered a bugfix for UEFI users."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-07-16 20:41:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We discussed it in IRC this morning [1]. I am OK with backporting this if all it entails is 1. backport, 2. new release of ironic-lib.

If we have to do more, eg, update stable ironic or IPA to use this released ironic-lib version, I don't think we can do it. At least, we'll need to discuss.

Olivier -- would you please confirm that all we need to do is backport and release ironic-lib?

(And why don't we have a bug/story for this? I'm not sure we're suppose to backport code changes w/o a bug but I'll leave that for Julia or someone else to decide/confirm...)

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2018-07-16.log.html#t2018-07-16T13:04:57"}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-17 05:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ruby & all, sorry not answering earlier as I am currently out on business trip.
I am afraid that the release of a new IPA is indeed mandatory as this fixes an issue
where you can not re-provision a node which was already provisioned without this
due to the existing partitioning info which is not completely cleaned up. (AFAIR in fact
as I noticed this few months ago). I can try to dig back into my memory/history and log a bug accordingly if necessary. Thanks a lot for everything'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-17 06:00:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just to complement what I just said, in the early stage of my trial fixes and as this method was just supposed to be exposed without any changes to other parts of ironic and more specifically the ironic python agent (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568524) as mentioned in the commit message. However, due to the final accepted changeset which also modifies the call to fixing GPT structures, making it executed in all cases the dependent changeset did not seem necessary any more in my opinion therefore abandoning the dependant changes.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-17 16:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-07-18 12:25:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

We need to update the commit message with the reason to backport and explanation why we think it's appropriate"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-18 12:44:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-18 15:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-19 12:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-21 05:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Many thanks for all the rework Julia'}, {'account_id': 21486, 'date': '2018-07-21 05:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-07-23 07:02:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 19578, 'date': '2018-07-23 09:59:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Fix GPT bug with whole disk images

Whole disk images with GPT partition tables would encounter
errors after the initial deploy as secondary copy of the
GPT partition table did not match the first table. This is
something we explicitly need to act upon for ironic.

Original commit message:

As suggested by TheJulia, the `_fix_gpt_structs` code
which is currently not accessible/callable from outside of ironic-lib
should be exposed so that other code like ironic-python-agent
can use it such as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568524/

Continuation of backport commit message:

To enable backporting of this patch such that we can address
the bug that it fixes in older releases, the method has been
preserved as a hidden method with a leading underscore.

Change-Id: Icd824982d23966605fb179270bbf428cab23a41d
(cherry picked from commit a8097877830233035441aba9e0106fc5913399c2)

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I73a108cc2066b848dc60eb414c86a3f2a78461b3
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I73a108cc2066b848dc60eb414c86a3f2a78461b3

> (2 comments)

But actually, this commit actually covers the scenario you have mentioned.

    def test_compare_dimensions_removed_and_changed(self):
        self.fake_data['params']['dimensions'] = {
            'mem_reservation': 10}
        container_info = dict()
        # Here mem_limit and mem_reservation are already present 
        # Now we are updating only 'mem_reservation'.
        # Ideally it should return True stating that the docker
        # dimensions have been changed.
        container_info['HostConfig'] = {
            'CpuPeriod': 0, 'KernelMemory': 0, 'Memory': 10, 'CpuQuota': 0,
            'CpusetCpus': '1', 'CpuShares': 0, 'BlkioWeight': 0,
            'CpusetMems': '', 'MemorySwap': 0, 'MemoryReservation': 100}
        self.dw = get_DockerWorker(self.fake_data['params'])
        self.assertTrue(self.dw.compare_dimensions(container_info))

Did I miss anything?

I didn't add this test_case of course but if needed will add."}, {'account_id': 27977, 'date': '2018-07-18 10:23:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

 > mentioned.

commit_message:
Apply Resource Constraints to Openstack Services

This commit is to apply resource-constraints only to few OpenStack services.
Commit to apply constraints to other services will be made in coming commits.

Partially-Implements: blueprint resource-constraints

Change-Id: Icafa54baca24d2de64238222a5677b9d8b90e2aa

commit_message:
requirements.sh: ignore scipy and scikit-learn

'scikit-learn' requires 'numpy' and 'scipy' packages. Which take long
time to build.

We need 'numpy' for nova image but can ignore rest (they are needed by
'monasca_analytics' project we do not use).

On x86-64 architecture all those packages come as binaries from Pypi.

Change-Id: I36b6ca9d094f83d48e7fa41a7818441169bd04e6

commit_message:
bindep: install blas and lapack headers to build numpy on aarch64

Nova image requires 'numpy' and on aarch64 we need to build it. So we
need some headers.

Not needed on x86-64 as there numpy comes from Pypi as binary.

Change-Id: I5460f5a20e3f919806c014aa4511a6d3781f70ed

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-26 12:42:25.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I57a2bc5656b680e74e861ffbec7f55bbd5cc2f25
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/rocky

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I57a2bc5656b680e74e861ffbec7f55bbd5cc2f25

commit_message:
Skip quote '=' for token header

If the token is encoded by base64, it may contain '=' char
as well.

We should skip quoting it.

Change-Id: I1ca63d251fa366f0e8e58128d45b729a2489b65c
Partial-Bug: #1783290

commit_message:
Use list of dict for ip_addresses field in metadata

There is nothing using CIDR notation in the metadata.
For consistency, it's better to use a list of dict with address/netmask.

Change-Id: I66a5cd523f42761d06f32949dfc02c202e31ba9f

subject: Configure Keystone with detection_args for http_check detection plugin
messages:
[{'account_id': 27191, 'date': '2018-06-06 11:56:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27191, 'date': '2018-06-06 13:10:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27191, 'date': '2018-06-06 13:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-06-15 12:57:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27191, 'date': '2018-06-27 08:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27191, 'date': '2018-06-27 08:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-07-19 11:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-07-19 11:37:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-07-24 12:45:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

It's not working for `detection_args_json`. It's implemented only for `detection_args`.

So this works:
`monasca-setup -d HttpCheck --detection_args "keystone_url=http://192.168.10.6/identity keystone_project=d keystone_user=f keystone_password=p url=https://192.168.10.6"`

And this does not:
`monasca-setup -d HttpCheck --detection_args_json '{"url":"http://192.168.10.6","keystone_config":{"keystone_url":"http://192.168.10.6/identity","keystone_project":"d","keystone_user":"f","keystone_password":"p"}}'`'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-07-26 11:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-07-26 13:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

messages:
[{'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-15 14:13:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-15 14:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-15 17:22:24.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

we have gate problems again, please do not restore or recheck, I'll take care of this one when gate is back stable."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-15 18:28:30.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-19 13:57:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-28 11:44:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-29 17:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-06-29 17:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-03 12:58:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-04 10:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:32:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)

Looks good to me, but I've got a few questions inline.

The question about using the Ansible module is more generic -- there's a module for the image facts, etc. I suspect the answer may be that the module dependencies (specifically python-shade) are not present in the undercloud.

It could simplify some of this code a bit though."}, {'account_id': 9317, 'date': '2018-07-12 12:08:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I tested this, it works pretty well overall. I do have one question, and I'd like to see Tomas's comments addressed."}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-12 23:50:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-12 23:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-13 22:33:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-18 10:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-18 10:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-23 05:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-23 06:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-23 06:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-23 07:03:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I switched back to using direct API calls rather than Ansible's built-in os_* modules. The reason for this is that the os_* modules recognize OS_* environment variables (such as %OS_AUTH_TOKEN) and use them for authentication. Some of these variables are set by the Mistral workflow and the run-validation script and contain values valid for the undercloud -- which doesn't help us here, because we want to access the services on the overcloud. This either leads to authentication errors (e.g. when using undercloud auth data on an overcloud auth url) or instantiation errors (e.g. when an os_* module passes an undercloud token found in an env var to the auth class, but the auth_type is set to `password`)."}, {'account_id': 9317, 'date': '2018-07-23 15:39:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Works as intended. I'm ok with addressing the comment in a follow up patch."}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-07-25 09:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-26 07:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-07-26 07:37:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-07-26 08:00:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9317, 'date': '2018-07-26 08:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2

Just waiting for the CI before approving it.'}, {'account_id': 9317, 'date': '2018-07-26 10:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add a OpenShift on OpenStack HW validation

This validation checks if the requirements for an OpenShift installation on top
of an OpenStack overcloud are met.

Change-Id: I3af047aca3ccc5e173dc0de48ba07f28536933c5

commit_message:
Fix network config conflicts for containerized UC

Make net_config_override and undercloud_resource_registry_args
mutually exclusive. When net_config_override is defined, we do
not want resource_registry for the network config in tht, as
they might happen to be in the direct conflict.

Closes-bug: #1781577

Change-Id: I802b525d477fd29a2ad746256a342acb364b0d1d
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

> should the removed versions be removed here as well?

It depends, because sahara-tests supports more Sahara releases. The last tagged version (0.6.0) dropped Newton, I suspect we may want to drop Ocata in the next version (it depends when the extended support for Ocata ends), but anyway I think I left all the plugin/versions supported since Ocata.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-07-26 09:26:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Update per plugin service definitions used by few tests

Those definitions are used by some Tempest and Tempest-based tests.
- add all the plugin/versions available in Sahara releases currently
  supported by sahara-tests;
- removed the definitions for the old 'hdp' plugin, whose code
  was removed in the Newton cycle.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/577815
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/578084
Change-Id: Ic46234e174545026d25791765828eeff4ab37d55

commit_message:
Client support for custom initial number of replicas

Added support to specify the initial number of replica sets during
runtime creation. If not specified, the number of replicas in conf file
is taken as default.

Change-Id: I12e905df168c45b6902ec88a0bc554f8369b6cf5
Task: 23187
Story: 2003095

New releases of oslo.config support a 'mutable' parameter to Opts.
oslo.service provides an option here Icec3e664f3fe72614e373b2938e8dee53cf8bc5e

This commit is to use the same. This allows zun to benefit from

(owned by oslo.log) is made mutable. we should be able to turn debug

commit_message:
Enable mutable config in zun

New releases of oslo.config support a 'mutable' parameter to Opts.
oslo.service provides an option here Icec3e664f3fe72614e373b2938e8dee53cf8bc5e
allows services to tell oslo.service they want mutate_config_files to be
called by passing a parameter.

This commit is to use the same. This allows zun to benefit from
I1e7a69de169cc85f4c09954b2f46ce2da7106d90, where the 'debug' option
(owned by oslo.log) is made mutable. we should be able to turn debug
logging on and off by changing the config.

tc goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/rocky/enable-mutable-configuration.html

Change-Id: Ibcc0dea603416e98ddedbbffffa6518adf931cb3

commit_message:
Reduce duplication in federated auth APIs

The GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/projects and GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/domains
APIs were introduced to handle tokens from federated users, but now
that GET /v3/auth/projects and GET /v3/auth/domains know how to handle
federated tokens, they're just duplicate APIs.

In the past we deprecated these federated auth APIs, but they still
used separate code paths from GET /v3/auth/projects and GET
/v3/auth/domains. The two code paths are true duplication in that they
don't expect to differ over time and should provide the same user
experience.

Instead of running the risk that comes with two code paths that do the
same thing, we should consolidate them.

Conflicts:
  keystone/federation/controllers.py due to the fact that pre-Queens
  code used a different dependency framework. This was reworked in
  the Queens release, causing a conflict with this patch since it
  touches the same code.

Co-Authored-By: Kristi Nikolla <kristi@nikolla.me>

Closes-Bug: 1779205
Change-Id: Ib906c42e1dd2c2408ccd2e256ffd876af02af3fe
(cherry picked from commit df5d75571ed274b2964ed52048768c6d9f24d138)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 10:42:34.000000000', 'message': 'Enhanced checkdisk for undercloud

The main issue with the current check is, we do not take into
account specific locations that can have a dedicated volume.

In order to correct that, we provide a list of locations known
for needing disk space, set a bottom limit, and check what is
actually mounted on the node.
Based on that, we loop on the "mounted volume of interest", and
check the free disk space for each of them.

That way, we ensure we can, at least, deploy the undercloud
without any trouble.

As we have now a fixed list, this can also help operators understanding
WHERE space needs to be allocated, and to what extend.

Please note: the listed "min_size" are the really minimal space needed,
and are probably not sufficient for a productive environment.

Another patch regarding the documentation will be provided once this
change is accepted and merged, in order to reflect this new mode of
calculation.

Change-Id: I71cf319270bfec50304f24a09da34d0ea8b1ecd8

commit_message:
Enhanced checkdisk for undercloud

The main issue with the current check is, we do not take into
account specific locations that can have a dedicated volume.

In order to correct that, we provide a list of locations known
for needing disk space, set a bottom limit, and check what is
actually mounted on the node.
Based on that, we loop on the "mounted volume of interest", and
check the free disk space for each of them.

That way, we ensure we can, at least, deploy the undercloud
without any trouble.

As we have now a fixed list, this can also help operators understanding
WHERE space needs to be allocated, and to what extend.

This patch also take into account the future deprecation of top-level
facts in Ansible.

Please note: the listed "min_size" are the really minimal space needed,
and are probably not sufficient for a productive environment.

Another patch regarding the documentation will be provided once this
change is accepted and merged, in order to reflect this new mode of
calculation.

Change-Id: I71cf319270bfec50304f24a09da34d0ea8b1ecd8

commit_message:
Fix tempest related files permissions for tempest container

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583940/ added tempest user with
  tempest container to fix tempest init log issue and it broke the
  container as all the directory with in tempest container and files
  getting mounted from host have different permision. It fixes the
  same.

* It moves all the tempest related files to tempest_data dir and then
  mount the same to tempest container by changing dir permission if
  tempest user is present else run the docker run as it is.

* Moving tempest dir creation step under container shell script

Change-Id: I9696b490e5d4646044de5258c676a357ee2779bb
Closes-Bug: #1783055
Depends-On: I20f04e8b821058a89a5464c9be1bb14d30f1f223

commit_message:
Remove cloudwatch packages during upgrade

We should remove the packages as part of both normal upgrade
and FFU, otherwise there can be conflicts.

Change-Id: Ibd2c5a8735b53f62309a63b143d4f475b49184a0
Closes-Bug: #1748548

I understand that there is a nova bug, but still without testing and with knowing that this feature will not work, we should wait for release.

So here is the plan:
1: We should have test cases(as i commented).
2: Setup multi node job to make sure both test are running on gate..
3: Lets wait till issue fixed in nova side.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-12 03:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

Hi Dharmendra,

Anti-Affinity - Multi-Cell nova deployment
 Anti-affinity policy will work only in case user has requested more than one instance in a single API request.
i.e. $openstack server create --flavor m1.tiny --image cirros --hint group=<uuid> --min 2 --max 2 <instance_name>

 Late anti-affinity check (on compute host) is not allowed in Multi-Cell nova deployment as it cannot access API
database where the instance_group information is present.


Anti-Affinity - Single-Cell nova deployment
 - Anti-affinity policy will work in case user has requested more than one instance in a single API request.
 i.e. $openstack server create --flavor m1.tiny --image cirros --hint group=<uuid> --min 2 --max 2 <instance_name>

 - It will also work if user has made separate requests to create servers using the same server group provided late
anti-affinity check is enabled.
  -- Below config options should be enabled in nova compute conf file
     CONF.workarounds.disable_group_policy_check_upcall=False
      In multi-cell deployment, it should be set to True
      In single-cell deployment, it should be set to False (default is False)
     CONF.filter_scheduler.track_instance_changes
      In multi-cell deployment, it should be set to False
      In single-cell deployment, it should be set to True (default is True)'}, {'account_id': 26588, 'date': '2018-07-12 05:05:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

Hi Tushar and Dharmendra,'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-12 09:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-12 09:59:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hi Dharmendra,

Added negative test in single cell deployment in which I have checked the VNF status goes into error state.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-12 13:11:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-12 13:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Fixed pep8 issue.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-13 02:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-13 02:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Added asserts to check second VDU is in error state.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-13 02:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-13 02:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 02:38:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 02:42:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

In PS 14, If multinode environment is  not present I have skipped "test_create_delete_vnf_with_placement_policy_anti_affinity" test  instead of failing this test. Also, added a note in release notes to explain 'late anti-affinity check' issue in nova multi-cells environment.

Only item pending is to make multinode job work.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 04:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 08:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

It seems that heat is using 'OpenStack-API-Version: compute 2.64' to create server group which doesn't support 'policies' parameter. It's changed to 'policy'. So heat is failing to create server group itself.

Nova-API logs
 http://logs.openstack.org/45/570845/14/check/tacker-functional-devstack/0138e0d/controller/logs/screen-n-api.txt.gz

 https://storyboard.openstack.org/?#!/story/2003017'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 09:22:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

>> We need to find out when this change was introduced in heat.
Reason why heat is failing to create server groups
 This change was introduced in compute micro version 2.64 in the below commit [1] on nova side. Heat uses python-novaclient  to make calls to nova service which discovers major version supported by nova service before making call and in this case it finds version as 2.64. Some of the functional tests will keep on failing until heat story 2003017 isn't resolved.

[1] : https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/ae40af621f7964ee5daac8ebdeb8cde37b1b879a#diff-a6ff12494b35c8b62a2479fc175e99a4"}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 10:21:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2018-07-18 10:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
Add placement policies support

- This patch aims to add support for following placement policies in
  addition to the default 'affinity' policy:
    anti-affinity
    soft-affinity
    soft-anti-affinity

- This patch adds respective functional/unit test cases. To test
  "anti-affinity" policy on the gate, changed the devstack functional
  jobs `nodeset` from the default single node to "openstack-two-node".

- This patch also adds respective documentation and usage guide for
  the above added policies.

Depends-On: I56a9cf4bb553c8026eec73212a3742d5eab17420
Co-Author: tpatil <tushar.vitthal.patil@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint vdu-affinity-policy
Change-Id: I18aaa9d00c8539ccc60cb6e70570dee124df70a3

commit_message:
Use jsonschema to validate efficacy indicators

This patch replaces voluptuous with JSON-schema to validate
efficacy indicator since in watcher we want to remove voluptuous
and use JSONSchema as our only JSON validation tool to keep consistency.

Change-Id: Iaa77566f1cdfdac03ce8e7d5a75406274c7d5298
Implements: blueprint replace-voplutuous-with-jsonschema

commit_message:
Rescheduling continuous audits from FAILED nodes

This patch set adds background job that reschedules CONTINUOUS
audits from FAILED to ACTIVE decision engine nodes using round-robin
algorithm. It also contains fix for main[1] HA PS about filtering audits.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/578102/

Partially-Implements: blueprint support-watcher-ha-active-active-mode
Change-Id: Ib248a6cd3adbd3927c47db6bb819300361492411

commit_message:
Add HA support

This patch set adds hostname field to Audit and Action Plan
objects to track services which execute these objects.

Change-Id: I786e419952925c380c969b12cc60f9a1004af96b
Partially-Implements: blueprint support-watcher-ha-active-active-mode

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 13:58:42.000000000', 'message': "More reliable gpg keys importing in DIB elements

We're still seeing apt-key failed to import gpg keys these days during
the images building in the gate jobs, the problem is keys.gnupg.net and
keyserver.ubuntu.com are both not stable according to [1] and [2], it's
better to adopt pool.sks-keyservers.net instead and with simple retries.

[1] https://www.gnupg.org/faq/gnupg-faq.html#new_user_default_keyserver
[2] https://sks-keyservers.net/overview-of-pools.php

Closes-Bug: #1579094

Change-Id: I0fe200d140f6f9c4d423dd498797a225e3295a71
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

commit_message:
More reliable gpg keys importing in DIB elements

We're still seeing apt-key failed to import gpg keys these days during
the images building in the gate jobs, the problem is keys.gnupg.net and
keyserver.ubuntu.com are both not stable according to [1] and [2], it's
better to adopt pool.sks-keyservers.net instead and with simple retries.

To reduce code duplication, this common apt-key importing function is
also moved to ubuntu-guest as an environment snippet.

[1] https://www.gnupg.org/faq/gnupg-faq.html#new_user_default_keyserver
[2] https://sks-keyservers.net/overview-of-pools.php

Closes-Bug: #1579094

Change-Id: I0fe200d140f6f9c4d423dd498797a225e3295a71
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix usage of "|" for tests

With the more recent versions of ansible, we should now use
"is" instead of the "|" sign for the tests.

This should fix it.

Change-Id: Ifec8022a02b0a5f259cadf5eb65ab74c51df3e73

commit_message:
Add filter option into `rally task detailed`

Sometimes, expect to see the specified scenarios detailed information,
for example, the task which includes many scenarios is a long information,
we could query the failed scenarios via the option --filter-by.
The sample:
1. query the failed scenarios
   rally task detailed --filter-by sla-failures
2. query the specified scenarios
   rally task detailed --filter-by scenarios=scenario1[,scenarios2...]

Change-Id: Ie7b20e57b651c622b865d03de56b6528ea5bd440

commit_message:
Use net-config-undercloud for UC in minimal config

config/general_config/minimal.yml tests Ironic provisioning
of VMs, therefore it requires eth1 to be included into br-ctlplane
bridge. T-h-t default net-config-undercloud.yaml provides that
functionality, while the one from
ci/common/net-config-simple-bridge.yaml does not.

Closes-Bug: #1782267

Change-Id: I460b2e0e47be737dfdfd84bbace81f7ee2f4f733
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

subject: Make all the jobs voting by default
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-23 07:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-23 12:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Seems to be voting now!'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2018-07-23 17:54:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2018-07-23 17:57:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We turned off voting a while back due to gate breaking issues. We are good to have it turned back on.

As far as built together... not quite. We actually publish keystone and cinder images for testing purposes (both are actively tested against) after each commit to keystone or nova.

LOCI as a whole strongly desires artifact builds where you can build nova or keystone seperate from each other at different times with the same results as a "delivered together" pipeline.

This is somewhat provable due to the upper-constraints.txt pinning, but not as exact as I would like since we don't technically test that currently.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-23 20:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> We turned off voting a while back due to gate breaking issues. We
 > are good to have it turned back on.
 > 
 > As far as built together... not quite. We actually publish keystone
 > and cinder images for testing purposes (both are actively tested
 > against) after each commit to keystone or nova.
 > 
 > LOCI as a whole strongly desires artifact builds where you can
 > build nova or keystone seperate from each other at different times
 > with the same results as a "delivered together" pipeline.
 > 
 > This is somewhat provable due to the upper-constraints.txt pinning,
 > but not as exact as I would like since we don't technically test
 > that currently.

Nova, Keystone, Neutron themselves are part of the same pipeline, so we could assume that something merging at some point in time was properly tested upstream together. So if these jobs are tracking all the appropriate HEAD of (master) branches, and they are done together, they would probably benefit from the same effects. That's what I meant. Not that it's strictly required nowadays anyway.'}, {'account_id': 27743, 'date': '2018-07-25 08:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1390, 'date': '2018-07-26 10:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

[{'created': '2018-07-23 07:51:43.000000000', 'message': 'Make all the jobs voting by default

OpenStack test changes of main repos like nova, keystone, neutron
in the same pipeline.  These are meant to be delivered together,
and therefore I think the images that are built by loci should
be built together. It is currently in-line with current loci
code, as there is already many loci jobs like loci-keystone,
loci-nova, loci-neutron, in the main repository.

However, while all the loci-* jobs are passing, only the
loci-requirements is voting.

This is a problem, as code could (theoretically) merge while
breaking a test.

This should fix it.

Change-Id: I6173b57b2b2f79341a9c57acc1aa74f1a9d9facf
'}]
commit_message:
Make all the jobs voting by default

OpenStack test changes of main repos like nova, keystone, neutron
in the same pipeline.  These are meant to be delivered together,
and therefore I think the images that are built by loci should
be built together. It is currently in-line with current loci
code, as there is already many loci jobs like loci-keystone,
loci-nova, loci-neutron, in the main repository.

However, while all the loci-* jobs are passing, only the
loci-requirements is voting.

This is a problem, as code could (theoretically) merge while
breaking a test.

This should fix it.

Change-Id: I6173b57b2b2f79341a9c57acc1aa74f1a9d9facf

commit_message:
remove enable_persistency from configuration.

Persistency wont be optional.
This parameter was not used so far thus is simply removed, without deprecating it.

Change-Id: I44baad84429c552b87364fa6659ca2ee193bef58

commit_message:
Rename ovs.py and ovs.OvsPort to switch.py and SwitchPort

The object now represents a generic switch port and not a specific ovs
port. The naming should represent it.

Change-Id: Ifa4f43eeaf50d807c46a6a034a98ba02c8dd5bfa
Partial-Bug: #1781376

commit_message:
Fix usage of "|" for tests

With the more recent versions of ansible, we should now use
"is" instead of the "|" sign for the tests.

This should fix it.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 15:20:36.000000000', 'message': "Reduce duplication in federated auth APIs

The GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/projects and GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/domains
APIs were introduced to handle tokens from federated users, but now
that GET /v3/auth/projects and GET /v3/auth/domains know how to handle
federated tokens, they're just duplicate APIs.

In the past we deprecated these federated auth APIs, but they still
used separate code paths from GET /v3/auth/projects and GET
/v3/auth/domains. The two code paths are true duplication in that they
don't expect to differ over time and should provide the same user
experience.

Instead of running the risk that comes with two code paths that do the
same thing, we should consolidate them.

Co-Authored-By: Kristi Nikolla <kristi@nikolla.me>

Closes-Bug: 1779205
Change-Id: Ib906c42e1dd2c2408ccd2e256ffd876af02af3fe
"}]
commit_message:
Reduce duplication in federated auth APIs

The GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/projects and GET /v3/OS-FEDERATION/domains
APIs were introduced to handle tokens from federated users, but now
that GET /v3/auth/projects and GET /v3/auth/domains know how to handle
federated tokens, they're just duplicate APIs.

In the past we deprecated these federated auth APIs, but they still
used separate code paths from GET /v3/auth/projects and GET
/v3/auth/domains. The two code paths are true duplication in that they
don't expect to differ over time and should provide the same user
experience.

Instead of running the risk that comes with two code paths that do the
same thing, we should consolidate them.

Co-Authored-By: Kristi Nikolla <kristi@nikolla.me>

Closes-Bug: 1779205
Change-Id: Ib906c42e1dd2c2408ccd2e256ffd876af02af3fe

commit_message:
ironic: Report resources as reserved when needed

The main use case for this is during ironic node cleaning, when,
instead of deleting the resource provider from placement we can
just report the resources as temporarily reserved.

This change also bumps placement API microversion used to update
inventory to '1.26' which allows to have inventories with
reserved value equal to total.

Closes-Bug: 1771577
blueprint: allow-reserved-equal-total-inventory
Change-Id: I1fd85860c96e8690fbcf93c8a2f02178168bfd5a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 06:22:18.000000000', 'message': 'Correcting split-stack document

The deployed-server-environment-output.json format generated
from the value of the DeployedServerEnvironment output of the
overcloud-baremetal stack is not a valid json format. And service
deployment command ultimately fails due to invalid json format.

Changing the output format to json and adding a jq filter to get
json format of output value.

Change-Id: I19ee30f20ce3c02a4c4d0dfb2b522818a15f629f
'}]
commit_message:
Correcting split-stack document

The deployed-server-environment-output.json format generated
from the value of the DeployedServerEnvironment output of the
overcloud-baremetal stack is not a valid json format. And service
deployment command ultimately fails due to invalid json format.

Changing the output format to json and adding a jq filter to get
json format of output value.

Change-Id: I19ee30f20ce3c02a4c4d0dfb2b522818a15f629f

commit_message:
Move metadata_service deployment out of DF code

The deployment should be done via deployment scripts and not in the
code (nor in plugin.sh directly, as to allow production deployment).
Moved the deployment to a script located in the tools directory, which
is now called from the plugin.sh, and may be called from any production
deployment mechanism.

Partial-Bug: #1781376
Change-Id: I90a7e8a87764354ab9e2a8ab149f00f2eaea94f5

subject: Enable mutable config in dragonflow
messages: [{'account_id': 16367, 'date': '2018-07-25 20:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20229, 'date': '2018-07-26 06:46:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17880, 'date': '2018-07-26 07:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 20:31:02.000000000', 'message': "Enable mutable config in dragonflow

New releases of oslo.config support a 'mutable' parameter to Opts.
oslo.service provides an option here Icec3e664f3fe72614e373b2938e8dee53cf8bc5e
allows services to tell oslo.service they want mutate_config_files to be
called by passing a parameter.

This commit is to use the same. This allows dragonflow to benefit from
I1e7a69de169cc85f4c09954b2f46ce2da7106d90, where the 'debug' option
(owned by oslo.log) is made mutable. we should be able to turn debug
logging on and off by changing the config.

tc goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/rocky/enable-mutable-configuration.html

Change-Id: I0ab4405413f786052fcf7f896b70e627926803ec
"}]
commit_message:
Enable mutable config in dragonflow

New releases of oslo.config support a 'mutable' parameter to Opts.
oslo.service provides an option here Icec3e664f3fe72614e373b2938e8dee53cf8bc5e
allows services to tell oslo.service they want mutate_config_files to be
called by passing a parameter.

This commit is to use the same. This allows dragonflow to benefit from
I1e7a69de169cc85f4c09954b2f46ce2da7106d90, where the 'debug' option
(owned by oslo.log) is made mutable. we should be able to turn debug
logging on and off by changing the config.

tc goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/rocky/enable-mutable-configuration.html

Change-Id: I0ab4405413f786052fcf7f896b70e627926803ec

messages:
[{'account_id': 28003, 'date': '2018-07-21 07:48:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20229, 'date': '2018-07-25 06:55:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17880, 'date': '2018-07-26 06:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-21 07:48:52.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I91abb5cb2e945abae630b07b1929ce1834d0d93d
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I91abb5cb2e945abae630b07b1929ce1834d0d93d

commit_message:
Removed unnecessary parantheses in yield statements

The 'yield' statement is not a function.
So it must always be followed by a space when yielding a value.

Change-Id: I518d34da400400b678448805ea19e554f48dac85

commit_message:
Drop mox3 from test-requirements.txt

create_stubs in test.helpers is also dropped in
this commit because this creates a stub using mox.
This is part of mox-removal community goal in Rocky.

Change-Id: I54b3679bf294f20910fae9bf9ee442769455415b
Closes-Bug: #1758388

commit_message:
[zanata] Fixes zanata_users with REST API

Zanata >=4 which is now on production utilizes REST API [1].
This commit fixes zanata_users.py to make compatible with
Zanata REST API and syncs translation_team.yaml up to date.

[1] http://zanata.org/zanata-platform/rest-api-docs/resource_LocalesResource.html

Change-Id: Ia99db310cff236797ef403ba5534d853ed63e3e3

can't test it, but won't None == None be incorrect?"}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-07-26 05:35:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I mean, if the value is None, I don't want to send it"}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-07-26 07:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> can't test it, but won't None == None be incorrect?

osc/osc_lib uses cliff, which uses argparse, and the default value for store_true/store_false is not None, but False and True respectively.

See:
https://docs.python.org/2/library/argparse.html#action

"'store_true' and 'store_false' - These are special cases of 'store_const' using for storing the values True and False respectively. In addition, they create default values of False and True respectively. For example:"

(and same for python3: https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#action )'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-07-26 07:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Allow operators to override docker_insecure_registries

Allow the operators to override the INSECURE_REGISTRY parameter without
hardcoding the local_ip and the admin VIP in all the cases.
If the operators want to override the whole parameter, they now can with
docker_insecure_registries parameter in undercloud.conf.

Related-Bug: #1767373
Change-Id: I2f734f603dd29e8b46bc6cf0c7af7c92488f0818

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 00:29:09.000000000', 'message': 'Do undercloud container prepare in external_deploy_tasks

This change moves docker-distribution from step 1 to step 0, then runs
container prepare as external_deploy_tasks.

The aim is to move these prepare tasks into their own service file so
they can be run on the undercloud and the overcloud, as an alternative
to having a dedicated mistral action for the overcloud prepare.

Change-Id: I2c82b6829e574424067130d1a369ff30030fb4bc
Blueprint: container-prepare-workflow
'}, {'created': '2018-07-12 03:27:52.000000000', 'message': 'Do undercloud container prepare in external_deploy_tasks

This change moves docker-distribution from step 1 to host_prep_tasks,
then runs container prepare as external_deploy_tasks.

The registry needs to be installed in host_prep_tasks, since it is
just before external_deploy_tasks step 1.

The aim is to move these prepare tasks into their own service file so
they can be run on the undercloud and the overcloud, as an alternative
to having a dedicated mistral action for the overcloud prepare.

Change-Id: I2c82b6829e574424067130d1a369ff30030fb4bc
Blueprint: container-prepare-workflow
'}, {'created': '2018-07-12 05:03:15.000000000', 'message': 'Do undercloud container prepare in external_deploy_tasks

This change moves docker and docker-distribution installation from
step 1 to host_prep_tasks, then runs container prepare as
external_deploy_tasks.

Container image prepare needs to run before any steps which require
container images, and it always needs to run on the undercloud because
it only ever populates the undercloud registry. Docker needs to be
installed in host_prep_tasks, since it is just before
external_deploy_tasks step 1.

The aim is to move these prepare tasks into their own service file so
they can be run during undercloud install and overcloud deploy, as an
alternative to having a dedicated mistral action for the overcloud
prepare.

Change-Id: I2c82b6829e574424067130d1a369ff30030fb4bc
Blueprint: container-prepare-workflow

The aim is to move these prepare tasks into their own service file so
