With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-11 20:49:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-11 20:50:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I expect this will come up during the Forum, but it's never too early to start discussing it."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-11 21:17:25.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-11 21:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-11 21:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-15 08:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like the idea here, but the wording is not optimal. See proposed alternate wording inline.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-15 18:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-16 17:12:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-05-17 01:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-17 11:40:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I am not in favour of this - we had this in the old incubation rules, and it caused issues where projects were in a catch-22, and no one would pout resources behind a stackforge project, but the stackforge project could not become an OpenStack project without people putting resources behind it.

The way it is currently worded muddies the waters - we may reject projects based on, or we may not, it is just a "risk"'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-17 16:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> I am not in favour of this - 

Fair.

> we had this in the old incubation rules,

No we didn't.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/incubation-integration-requirements.html#incubation

> and it caused issues where projects were in a catch-22, and no one would pout resources behind a stackforge project, but the stackforge project could not become an OpenStack project without people putting resources behind it.

All the more incentive to develop in the open from the beginning?

> The way it is currently worded muddies the waters - we may reject projects based on, or we may not, it is just a "risk"

That's the case already though. In the thread linked in the commit message - which started from the premise that this is an area of subjective judgement - a number of TC members expressed a willingness to reject new projects based on this criterion. If that's a widespread opinion (and this review should tell us whether it is or not) then applicants could be surprised by a roadblock that is documented only in some obscure ancient mailing list thread. Furthermore, by not stating this as an upfront requirement we're foregoing the ability to influence projects ahead of time by providing an incentive to be open from the beginning.

Some of the vagueness in the wording is intentional, because I didn't necessarily want future TC members to feel bound to reject a project on these grounds (and it's inevitably subjective - how diverse is enough?), more to make applicants aware in advance that it would be considered. I agree that the current wording is _too_ vague and I will try to shore it up a bit. If folks favour a hard condition then I wouldn't be opposed, but it didn't seem like the best way to get agreement.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-31 00:27:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-31 00:42:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Let's see what people think of this wording.

Nothing that has happened in the past week or two has changed my opinion about the importance of this ;)"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-31 08:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think that at this stage of the life of the OpenStack project, it is a reasonable addition.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-01 23:55:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I'm okay with this as is, with the caveat that we should probably be reviewing (and changing) this document more than we do.

I've reached a point where I'm disinclined to accept projects which are "new to openness". This was okay when we were striving for growth but now I think we should be striving for completeness and maturity. Given that, we should be inviting existing projects that will help round out a clarified vision of OpenStack.

That is: we should (as a broader community, not just the TC) identify gaps and seek out projects that fill them. Where no such project exists, we should try to inspire their creation.

In other words, I don't think we should be in the business of generally incubating.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-04 07:54:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I started commenting before reading the other reviews - I agree with mugsie that this presents a catch-22. I also think it's a bit dangerous to conflate openness with diversity."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-04 16:48:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-04 18:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-11 17:58:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I feel like there must be something I'm still failing to communicate about this. The change is very narrowly targeted at only the following scenario:

1) An organisation starts a closed-source project to do something. They make all of the hardest-to-reverse decisions about the project behind closed doors, without even asking the community for input (let alone getting any), and develop something that fits only their own use case.
2) For whatever reason, the organisation decides that 'open sourcing' the code is the solution to their problems. They do a code drop.
3) They continue developing the code, this time in the open, to widespread apathy. Nobody else cares about the project, or at least not enough to put their money where their mouth is and get involved.
4) The project applies to become an official part of OpenStack.

Would you vote to approve this project? I personally wouldn't. Furthermore, I think we should tell folks that at step 1 when they can avoid the original sin, and step 2 when they could still start a fresh project in the open from any empty repo with community involvement while still contributing the useful parts of their existing code, instead of only at step 4 when it's probably too late.

If the wording is conveying any other impression then we evidently still need to tweak it to make sure we're communicating clearly. Maybe we shouldn't use the words "signs of diversification in its contributor affiliations", to avoid confusion with the definition of the diverse affiliations tag?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-11 19:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I feel like there must be something I'm still failing to
 > communicate about this. The change is very narrowly targeted at
 > only the following scenario:
 > 
 > 1) An organisation starts a closed-source project to do something.
 > They make all of the hardest-to-reverse decisions about the project
 > behind closed doors, without even asking the community for input
 > (let alone getting any), and develop something that fits only their
 > own use case.
 > 2) For whatever reason, the organisation decides that 'open
 > sourcing' the code is the solution to their problems. They do a
 > code drop.
 > 3) They continue developing the code, this time in the open, to
 > widespread apathy. Nobody else cares about the project, or at least
 > not enough to put their money where their mouth is and get
 > involved.
 > 4) The project applies to become an official part of OpenStack.
 > 
 > Would you vote to approve this project? I personally wouldn't.
 > Furthermore, I think we should tell folks that at step 1 when they
 > can avoid the original sin, and step 2 when they could still start
 > a fresh project in the open from any empty repo with community
 > involvement while still contributing the useful parts of their
 > existing code, instead of only at step 4 when it's probably too
 > late.
 > 
 > If the wording is conveying any other impression then we evidently
 > still need to tweak it to make sure we're communicating clearly.
 > Maybe we shouldn't use the words "signs of diversification in its
 > contributor affiliations", to avoid confusion with the definition
 > of the diverse affiliations tag?

This version is quite clear. Maybe what we want to do is turn this into a new section of the document that bypasses saying "we're not going to vote to accept your projects" but does say "we might not vote to accept projects like this because they have a history of not working out well". That allows the TC at the time of the application to use their judgement while still signaling that it's fine for that judgement to include a reluctance to dealing with code drops.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-12 19:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> That allows the TC at the time of the application to use their judgement

I'm open to that if it's clearer, although "shows signs of diversification" already leaves very wide latitude for individual judgement (by design).'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-14 16:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-15 09:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Rollcall-Vote

I agree asking for "signs of diversification" in case the project was started as a closed thing is not too much to ask.

The wording is a bit absolute though (especially the use of the word "permitted"), which does not sit well with the subjectivity of the rule. I think it needs some sparkling of "SHOULD" over it. Basically the rule should be spelled out so that new projects know that they can be rejected due to it, but this is not a hard rule (and can't be due to the amount of subjectivity in it).'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-07-04 08:13:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

I'm not in favor of this partly for the reasons I mentioned in the Adjutant review - even a project that is doing everything right from the beginning may not "show signs of diversification". Whether it's a code drop or a completely open source project, it's not fair to ask projects to gain more contributors before they're even able to leverage the visibility they seek to get from becoming official.

I think it's fair to wonder about the viability of a code-drop project, but tying it specifically to contributor affiliation is too much of a leap.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-07-10 20:19:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-07-12 13:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think this strikes the right balance'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-12 17:22:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-07-13 20:44:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-16 15:38:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-07-17 11:58:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-17 18:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I think this makes the point we want - that we really want projects that are living the 4 opens from the start, and that it will from part of our process when we are considering new projects'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-20 21:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This change has enough votes to be approved on 2018-07-21 but I will hold it open to give Colleen a chance to comment on the most recent draft, since she had an objection to an earlier draft.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-07-22 13:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

The gentler wording seems more appropriate to me, thanks'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-22 16:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-07-23 14:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1 -Code-Review

I meant RC +1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-07-23 17:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

"we might not vote to accept projects like this because they have a history of not working out well" is basically why I abstained from the Adjutant application. I'm unconvinced it's a compelling enough argument to sway >50% of the TC.

That said, this addition harmonizes with my opinions and, I believe, with the intent of the four opens.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-07-24 08:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> "we might not vote to accept projects like this because they have a
 > history of not working out well" is basically why I abstained from
 > the Adjutant application. I'm unconvinced it's a compelling enough
 > argument to sway >50% of the TC.
 > 
 > That said, this addition harmonizes with my opinions and, I
 > believe, with the intent of the four opens.

I think this points to something we might want to talk about at the PTG. When we are evaluating projects for "official" some think of it is as enabling a thing which has potential to be in alignment with the four opens, some think of it as accepting a thing which has (already) demonstrated alignment with the four opens.

Another way to say the same thing: one way to look at officialness is enabling success, another way is rewarding success.

Obviously neither of these binaries are actually binaries, not do they represent the true model of people's thoughts, but they do provide an interpretive lens that might be useful to discuss.

If we can decide what we are doing it might make things a bit more clear for aspirants.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-07-24 11:49:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-07-25 19:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-07-25 20:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1 Workflow+1

Approved :)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 20:49:37.000000000', 'message': "Clarify new project requirements for affiliation diversity

From discussions on the mailing list[1] it seems that there is support
for the idea that projects that being with a code drop present a higher
risk of failing to attract contributors outside of the initial
developers.

This change aims to clearly communicate the TC's position to projects
considering applying to join OpenStack, by explicitly stating both that
code drops will be required to demonstrate traction with outside
contributors, and that no such requirement for diverse contributor
affiliation exists in general.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129703.html

Change-Id: I8ee9bb08ee143402e2b8240e3cbe6ba5b0684596
"}, {'created': '2018-05-31 00:27:47.000000000', 'message': "Clarify new project requirements for affiliation diversity

From discussions on the mailing list[1] it seems that there is support
for the idea that projects that being with a code drop present a higher
risk of failing to attract contributors outside of the initial
developers.

This change aims to clearly communicate the TC's position to projects
considering applying to join OpenStack, by explicitly stating both that
code drops will be required to demonstrate traction with outside
contributors, and that no such requirement for diverse contributor
affiliation exists in general.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129703.html

Change-Id: I8ee9bb08ee143402e2b8240e3cbe6ba5b0684596
"}, {'created': '2018-07-10 20:19:19.000000000', 'message': "Clarify new project requirements for community engagement

From discussions on the mailing list[1] it seems that there is support
for the idea that projects that being with a code drop present a higher
risk of failing to attract interest outside of the initial developers.

This change aims to clearly communicate the TC's position to projects
considering applying to join OpenStack, by explicitly stating both that
code drops may be required to demonstrate traction in the community, and
that no such requirement for community engagement exists in general.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129703.html

Change-Id: I8ee9bb08ee143402e2b8240e3cbe6ba5b0684596
"}]
commit_message:
Clarify new project requirements for community engagement

From discussions on the mailing list[1] it seems that there is support
for the idea that projects that being with a code drop present a higher
risk of failing to attract interest outside of the initial developers.

This change aims to clearly communicate the TC's position to projects
considering applying to join OpenStack, by explicitly stating both that
code drops may be required to demonstrate traction in the community, and
that no such requirement for community engagement exists in general.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129703.html

Change-Id: I8ee9bb08ee143402e2b8240e3cbe6ba5b0684596

by the infra team before they can be added to governance.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-18 06:52:02.000000000', 'message': "Do not quote token

The token in request header may contain url char, such as '+',
if quote it, '+' will change to '%2B' which will lead to 401 error.

Our CI doesn't notice this bug because Keystone use fernet token
which doesn't contain url char by default. But token format in
keystone is plugable, some out-tree token formats may contain
url char (for example, PKI/PKIZ token).

So we should skip quote token to avoiding information changing.

Change-Id: I5aa71b3e2b9b19581e46ccf8a80eda5d637f17d1
"}, {'created': '2018-07-18 08:01:58.000000000', 'message': "Do not quote token

commit_message:
Do not quote '+' for token header

The token in request header may contain url char, such as '+',
if quote it, '+' will change to '%2B' which will lead to 401 error.

Our CI doesn't notice this bug because Keystone use fernet token
which doesn't contain url char by default. But token format in
keystone is plugable, some out-tree token formats may contain
url char (for example, PKI/PKIZ token).

So we should skip quote token to avoiding information changing.

Closes-bug: #1783290
Change-Id: I5aa71b3e2b9b19581e46ccf8a80eda5d637f17d1

commit_message:
show the relative earliest date of approval

When a change is not ready to be approved, show the rule for the
earliest date on which it could be.

Change-Id: Ib7f1b3e491fd078fb6697580018f3b05658bd422
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-05 16:53:35.000000000', 'message': "Introduce new TokenModel object

Our previous token model (``KeystoneToken``) was built to accept
complete token responses and use reflection to be more pythonic. Now
that we're no longer supporting token providers or storage layers
that rely on passing around full token responses, we can introduce
a more pythonic way of building tokens.

This commit introduces a new TokenModel object that is intended to be
used with composition, starting with a blank state and allowing parts
of the application to fill in the blanks. This should hopefully make
our entire authentication and validation API paths more clear and
understandable.

Change-Id: I2e461e7fdf4f47547e07fc279ec4e6fbd86f23ad

Change-Id: I2e461e7fdf4f47547e07fc279ec4e6fbd86f23ad
"}, {'created': '2018-06-21 15:56:46.000000000', 'message': "Introduce new TokenModel object

Our previous token model (``KeystoneToken``) was built to accept
complete token responses and use reflection to be more pythonic. Now
that we're no longer supporting token providers or storage layers
that rely on passing around full token responses, we can introduce
a more pythonic way of building tokens.

This commit introduces a new TokenModel object that is intended to be
used with composition, starting with a blank state and allowing parts
of the application to fill in the blanks. This should hopefully make
our entire authentication and validation API paths more clear and
understandable.

The following are a few benefits of adopting the new model.

First, this helps us simplify the interface between the token provider
API and the actual token providers. The token providers shouldn't have
to understand the API contract in order to work. Likewise, if we add
another API version, we shouldn't need to change multiple token
providers to ensure the API contract isn't violated depending on which
one is being used.

Second, this forces us to translate the token model into a token
response in a single place (e.g. the controller), isolating where we
represent API contracts. The is mostly an extension of the first
point, but it helps us be explicit in what we build and give to a
user. This type of architecture should help us avoid letting bugs like
bug 1763510 slip through our fingers.

Third, and somewhat subjectively, this makes the code easier to read
by dealing with objects in pythonic ways as opposed to understanding
large data structures in the controller, manager, and driver layers of
a subsystem.

Change-Id: I2e461e7fdf4f47547e07fc279ec4e6fbd86f23ad

commit_message:
Introduce new TokenModel object

Our previous token model (``KeystoneToken``) was built to accept
complete token responses and use reflection to be more pythonic. Now
that we're no longer supporting token providers or storage layers
that rely on passing around full token responses, we can introduce
a more pythonic way of building tokens.

This commit introduces a new TokenModel object that is intended to be
used with composition, starting with a blank state and allowing parts
of the application to fill in the blanks. This should hopefully make
our entire authentication and validation API paths more clear and
understandable.

The following are a few benefits of adopting the new model.

First, this helps us simplify the interface between the token provider
API and the actual token providers. The token providers shouldn't have
to understand the API contract in order to work. Likewise, if we add
another API version, we shouldn't need to change multiple token
providers to ensure the API contract isn't violated depending on which
one is being used.

Second, this forces us to translate the token model into a token
response in a single place (e.g. the controller), isolating where we
represent API contracts. The is mostly an extension of the first
point, but it helps us be explicit in what we build and give to a
user. This type of architecture should help us avoid letting bugs like
bug 1763510 slip through our fingers.

Third, and somewhat subjectively, this makes the code easier to read
by dealing with objects in pythonic ways as opposed to understanding
large data structures in the controller, manager, and driver layers of
a subsystem.

Partial-Bug: 1778945
Change-Id: I2e461e7fdf4f47547e07fc279ec4e6fbd86f23ad

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-23 23:23:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix SLO delete for accounts with non-ASCII names.

If an account contains non-ASCII characters, currently SLO delete code
will fail, as get_slo_segments() method receives a unicode object, but
UTF-8 encoded account name. Attempting to concatenate the strings fails
with a UnicodeError, as it tries to use the ASCII codec to decode the
UTF-8 encoded account name.

This patch allows accounts with non-ASCII characters in their names to
delete SLOs.

Change-Id: I619d41e62c16b25bd5f58d300a3dc71aa4dc75c2
'}]
commit_message:
Fix SLO delete for accounts with non-ASCII names.

If an account contains non-ASCII characters, currently SLO delete code
will fail, as get_slo_segments() method receives a unicode object, but
UTF-8 encoded account name. Attempting to concatenate the strings fails
with a UnicodeError, as it tries to use the ASCII codec to decode the
UTF-8 encoded account name.

This patch allows accounts with non-ASCII characters in their names to
delete SLOs.

Change-Id: I619d41e62c16b25bd5f58d300a3dc71aa4dc75c2

[{'created': '2018-07-25 19:19:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix errors in package metadata

Package metadata was missing author or maintainer information that is
now required due to package checks run by pypi in order to upload. These
checks can be performed locally by running the command:

python setup.py check -s -r

This adds author information to match what is commonly used in other
OpenStack package metadata.

Change-Id: I671560358d8ea0f6c878df2595c26f15e9f8b514
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix errors in package metadata

Package metadata was missing author or maintainer information that is
now required due to package checks run by pypi in order to upload. These
checks can be performed locally by running the command:

python setup.py check -s -r

This adds author information to match what is commonly used in other
OpenStack package metadata.

Change-Id: I671560358d8ea0f6c878df2595c26f15e9f8b514
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Run undeploy_plan workflow to delete deployment

* create separate UndeployProgress components to track
  deletion of deployment
* unify deploy/undeploy transition when issuing the workflow using UI
  state rather than custom UI deployment state (STARTING_DEPLOYMENT)

Depends-On: Ibd1da1aee8415712b9a418c6738f6ea9a2828a55
Implements: blueprint config-download-ui
Change-Id: Idec2534a583f6bea7c74bbdb8a08b9a81b7aa3f8

commit_message:
Be more precise with conductor group API tests

Use 1.45 as the "bad" version for conductor group API tests, as this is
the last version that does not support it.

Change-Id: I20ae5531e3d52eb270411cfa068d3c20211bcd5e

[{'account_id': 24574, 'date': '2018-07-25 02:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24574, 'date': '2018-07-25 04:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11797, 'date': '2018-07-25 06:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Tone,

I'd like to see this patch written in terms of what it is enabling, rather than it being written in terms of passing the RefStack tests. The RefStack test suite for validating OpenStack are meant for interoperability, so we want to make the deployment fully interoperable with other OpenStack Powered platforms. In those terms, the clients of the cloud expect ceph_rgw to be there and behave a certain way. 

This is not a patch to make the tests pass, it is a patch, surely, to make the deployed cloud "object storage interoperable", if that makes sense. 

Any other thoughts welcome. 

Please, amend the variable name as well as the patch description on these terms.'}, {'account_id': 24574, 'date': '2018-07-25 07:22:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

 > I'd like to see this patch written in terms of what it is enabling,

 > interoperable with other OpenStack Powered platforms. In those

 > behave a certain way.
 > 
 > This is not a patch to make the tests pass, it is a patch, surely,
 > to make the deployed cloud "object storage interoperable", if that
 > makes sense.
 > 
 > Any other thoughts welcome.
 > 
 > Please, amend the variable name as well as the patch description on
 > these terms.

Hi Gema,

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 02:19:02.000000000', 'message': 'Support RefStack test with ceph-rgw in Kolla-ansible

When run RefStack test to validate "object storage" with ceph-rgw,
all the test cases are failed.

The patch makes ceph-rgw support RefStack "object storage" test.
It is controlled by the option "ceph_rgw_tempest_test".

After change the option, please run "reconfigure" command to activate
it.

Closes-Bug: #1783456

Change-Id: Ibf3eb52280e197965caef08a44ae226c4f884cb5
Signed-off-by: tone.zhang <tone.zhang@arm.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-07-25 08:31:15.000000000', 'message': 'Improve ceph-rgw compatibility with Swift API in Kolla-ansible

By default ceph-rgw is not completely comaptible with Swift API,
because the restriction for Swift INFO API.[0]

The patch improve ceph-rgw compatibility with Swift API. It is
controlled by the option "ceph_rgw_compatibility" in
ansible/group_vars/all.yml.

After change the option, please run "reconfigure" command to activate
it.

Closes-Bug: #1783456

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/17967

Change-Id: Ibf3eb52280e197965caef08a44ae226c4f884cb5

commit_message:
Improve ceph-rgw compatibility with Swift API in Kolla-ansible

By default ceph-rgw is not completely comaptible with Swift API,
because of the restriction for Swift INFO API.[0]

The patch improve ceph-rgw compatibility with Swift API. It is
controlled by the option "ceph_rgw_compatibility" in
ansible/group_vars/all.yml.

After changing the option, run the "reconfigure" command to enable.

Closes-Bug: #1783456

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/17967

Change-Id: Ibf3eb52280e197965caef08a44ae226c4f884cb5
Signed-off-by: tone.zhang <tone.zhang@arm.com>

commit_message:
Update manila environment file names

to eliminate special 'docker' names.

Containerized manila is now the standard way to deploy
so we can avoid confusion by just using the regular
manila environment file names for these rather than having
some manila environment files with 'docker' in their names.

Note that we are using the content of
environments/manila-cephfsnative-config-docker.yaml
for
environments/manila-cephfsnative-config.yaml.  This resolves an
issue wherein the parameters in the latter file were not updated
when support for the CephFS-NFS back end was added [1].

Closes-Bug: #1782622

[1] Ib408c7827e5fba0c1b01388db26363806fc64370

Change-Id: I08431d848158846a434fecc98d3bee838c7fad68

Related Kayobe change passes CI when it depends on this change: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/581053/.'}, {'account_id': 9820, 'date': '2018-07-13 01:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23717, 'date': '2018-07-19 15:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2018-07-20 08:17:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-07-25 17:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-07-25 17:44:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-10 11:45:46.000000000', 'message': "Fix sudoers in bootstrap-servers when user != group

In some cases we may want a configuration in which the kolla user's
primary group name is not the same as their username. Doing this
currently breaks the sudoers configuration, since user entries should
reference a user, or a group prefixed with a '%'.

There does not seem to be a good reason to give root privileges to the
entire group (which sometimes may be a shared group), so let's revert to
giving only the user root privileges.

See kayobe CI test [1] in which a different user and group were
configured, leading to permission denied when using kolla ansible.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/53/581053/2/check/kayobe-overcloud-centos/a70168e

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I677778ebd0de58df0adfa2a8705f161ec5552283
"}]
commit_message:
Fix sudoers in bootstrap-servers when user != group

In some cases we may want a configuration in which the kolla user's
primary group name is not the same as their username. Doing this
currently breaks the sudoers configuration, since user entries should
reference a user, or a group prefixed with a '%'.

There does not seem to be a good reason to give root privileges to the
entire group (which sometimes may be a shared group), so let's revert to
giving only the user root privileges.

See kayobe CI test [1] in which a different user and group were
configured, leading to permission denied when using kolla ansible.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/53/581053/2/check/kayobe-overcloud-centos/a70168e

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I677778ebd0de58df0adfa2a8705f161ec5552283

commit_message:
Fix usage of "|" for tests

With the more recent versions of ansible, we should now use
"is" instead of the "|" sign for the tests.

This should fix it.

Change-Id: I639c18dda7950243fc70028c9b795c3f24ef8e7a

commit_message:
Fix rally-task-neutron-with-extensions job

The lbaas scenarios have been removed into rally-task-load-balancing job,
so remove them from rally-task-neutron-with-extensions.

Change-Id: Icfba20603dd408866e4ed92d18d74327f1c04df3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-23 12:28:29.000000000', 'message': "zuul: remove jobs with overcloud

We switched the default to containerized undercloud so most of the CI
now is deploying a containerized undercloud, therefore doesn't use
instack-undercloud.
Updating the zuul layout so we only run the jobs that actually test
instack-undercloud.

Change-Id: I80c1740219b00e857b53ba919f705a20fe8d3a52
"}]
commit_message:
zuul: remove jobs with overcloud

We switched the default to containerized undercloud so most of the CI
now is deploying a containerized undercloud, therefore doesn't use
instack-undercloud.
Updating the zuul layout so we only run the jobs that actually test
instack-undercloud.

Change-Id: I80c1740219b00e857b53ba919f705a20fe8d3a52

messages:
[{'account_id': 22776, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-28 17:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is this trying to address the same issue as in story 1747836, or something subtly different?'}, {'account_id': 22776, 'date': '2018-07-02 20:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Is this trying to address the same issue as in story 1747836, or
 > something subtly different?

Slightly different in the sense, this is one level after the other issue, but pointing at it indirectly. This is just part of making the update operation more robust.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-13 03:21:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Hi my question is somehow the same as Zane's :)"}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2018-07-24 09:00:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've proposed a patch (for another similar bug) to ignore the error at the origin, rather than propagating it and not translating other properties. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/585171/ should probably fix your issue as well."}, {'account_id': 22776, 'date': '2018-07-25 18:16:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I've proposed a patch (for another similar bug) to ignore the error
 > at the origin, rather than propagating it and not translating other
 > properties. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/585171/ should
 > probably fix your issue as well.

Okay, Thanks:). I will abandon this."}, {'account_id': 22776, 'date': '2018-07-25 18:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Fix is proposed here  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/585171/.'}]

Story: 2002740
Task: 22590

commit_message:
Translation validation of older properties fails

This fixes a scenario where translation validation of older properties
fails due to those properties being deleted during a stack update.

Change-Id: Idad9a42020ca697b532740a823736c7d22bc3b2e
Story: 2002740
Task: 22590

commit_message:
Document Ceph upgrade test scenario

Document process of upgrading Ceph version without
downtime for Openstack components.
- install ceph charts with luminous v12.2.4 images
- deploy Openstack charts
- update ceph chars to luminous v12.2.5

Change-Id: I98194552b102f57ffb891461fe67d3fdd27d2464

commit_message:
Images: Add fluent profile to openstack images that support it

This PS adds the fluent prfile to openstack images that include
a version of oslo.log capable of using this formatter (>= ocata).

Change-Id: Idefd41683b4d515e7e9e3b457cd8d6133de6cbf6
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
OS::Nova::Server: Extend addresses attr to include network

This change adds 'network' to the addresses attribute of the
OS::Nova::Server resource. This enables resolving the
properties of the neutron network for the server resource.

Story: 1766946
Task: 19690
Change-Id: I5bef751982919103ecbefeee64bf0f2cbede0cd0

commit_message:
Add command to show all service versions

Knowing what services and what versions of those services exist on a
cloud isn't always a spectacular experience. Add a command that will use
get_all_version_data from keystoneauth to produce a report of the
available services and the version info for each service.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584944
Change-Id: I84751c175d0c5f6d857a5473d2db6d5f1b41f946

[{'created': '2018-07-24 19:58:52.000000000', 'message': "Add vif_plug_noop to setup.cfg packages

The following error is being seen in the gate n-cpu logs:

  ERROR stevedore.extension [-] Could not load 'noop': No module named
  vif_plug_noop.noop

Change ba61a981171b3514219eb6ecf306e421f99ce127 added the noop plugin

Change-Id: If4816a63cb19c4b593a6994a3a9fe05a2196761d
"}]
commit_message:
Add vif_plug_noop to setup.cfg packages

The following error is being seen in the gate n-cpu logs:

  ERROR stevedore.extension [-] Could not load 'noop': No module named
  vif_plug_noop.noop

Change ba61a981171b3514219eb6ecf306e421f99ce127 added the noop plugin
but missed adding it to the packages list.

Closes-Bug: #1783403

Change-Id: If4816a63cb19c4b593a6994a3a9fe05a2196761d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-12 05:54:24.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I4ef8678c433cc593db64f596a320d16bc1215eb1
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I4ef8678c433cc593db64f596a320d16bc1215eb1

Now keystonemiddleware use oslo.cache to init the
MemcacheClientPool. The MemcacheClientPool in
Olso.cache needs (urls, arguments, **kwargs) parameter
to init, but keystonemiddleware passed only
(urls, **kwargs). Then it leads the error:
__init__() takes exactly 3 arguments (2 given)

This patch fixed this issue.

Please note that even this error is fixed, set
"memcache_use_advanced_pool = True" will lead another
error, see bug #1747565 for the detail. It will be
fixed in the following patch.

Closes-bug: #1748160
Change-Id: I642f959ab8b010207314312a6b6a06a6de23e92c
(cherry picked from commit ce06c0ce1035964ecf117bd56f769174508dc269)

commit_message:
Add arguments for MemcacheClientPool init

Now keystonemiddleware use oslo.cache to init the
MemcacheClientPool. The MemcacheClientPool in
Olso.cache needs (urls, arguments, **kwargs) parameter
to init, but keystonemiddleware passed only
(urls, **kwargs). Then it leads the error:
__init__() takes exactly 3 arguments (2 given)

This patch fixed this issue.

Please note that even this error is fixed, set
"memcache_use_advanced_pool = True" will lead another
error, see bug #1747565 for the detail. It will be
fixed in the following patch.

Conflicts:
	keystonemiddleware/tests/unit/auth_token/test_cache.py

Closes-bug: #1748160
Change-Id: I642f959ab8b010207314312a6b6a06a6de23e92c
(cherry picked from commit ce06c0ce1035964ecf117bd56f769174508dc269)

commit_message:
tox: Don't create '.pyc' files

Our tox.ini was trying to use find but failing because it was not
added to whitelist_externals. Rather than correct that, we can
remove it entirely by adjusting tox to no longer create '.pyc'
files, so we no longer have to delete them.

Nova previously did this [1] to improve performance, but then had
to revert it [2] because of a tox bug. That bug has since been
fixed [3], so we should be ok to do this.

[1] 0d6d1616b9a05f1c3e1e34cb235fee327196d423
[2] 233160644f4f0a17177fffe8a1e6db1341e61ad4
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582392/1/tox.ini@28

Change-Id: I11cbf81160ba2eeefcce19ed25930c39e17449b7

Change-Id: I653403bfc5431741807edef57df58e05e679900b
'}]
commit_message:
Make sudoers config optional in bootstrap-servers

In some environments it may not be desirable to modify the sudoers
configuration. This change makes this part of bootstrap-servers
optional, based on the create_kolla_user_sudoers variable.

Change-Id: I653403bfc5431741807edef57df58e05e679900b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 13:49:46.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify build requirements

LOCI build requires a docker version >= 17.0.5 to work,
due to the FROM given as argument (See this new feature
in the 17.0.5 release changelog [1])

Without this patch, a new contributor might think the image
building is broken, while LOCI works perfectly fine.

This patch solves the problem by being explicit in the minimum
required version.

[1]: https://docs.docker.com/release-notes/docker-ce/#17050-ce-2017-05-04

Change-Id: I4ebdcbd641607ffce3a20731cbf035c7a9a9af65
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify build requirements

LOCI build requires a docker version >= 17.0.5 to work,
due to the FROM given as argument (See this new feature
in the 17.0.5 release changelog [1])

Without this patch, a new contributor might think the image
building is broken, while LOCI works perfectly fine.

This patch solves the problem by being explicit in the minimum
required version.

[1]: https://docs.docker.com/release-notes/docker-ce/#17050-ce-2017-05-04

Change-Id: I4ebdcbd641607ffce3a20731cbf035c7a9a9af65

commit_message:
Allow custom --bip CIDR for docker options

The default docker0 brige should be normally given a
value that does not conflict to any of the existing
networks' CIDR ranges.

If there is a conflict for the default value `172.31.0.1/24`,
allow users to alter the the docker service startup ``--bip``
option via ``DockerNetworkOptions``.

Change-Id: I9b3e729ba48811415106c9fa460cd5a677067fb7
Closes-Bug: #1783271
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit beff4795a59dd5fc9b52cc020df9bca49af87528)

commit_message:
Add initial support for Fernet tokens

Starting OpenStack Rocky the currently used `uuid` token format
is no longer supported and we need to change to use `fernet` tokens.

This change provides basic functionalty to initialize fernet token
repository and distribute keys to non-leader units.

A configuration option is also added allowing change of token format
in a controlled manner prior to upgrading to OpenStack Rocky.

Further work is required to implement key rotation, actions etc. and
these topics will be addressed in separate commits.

The commit also fixes a instance of missing release check for writing
of `policy.json`, and a few places where writing of `policy.json`
previously was omitted.

Change-Id: I1d0ff22a5f091b02f5700412745572c246103e9e

commit_message:
Fix dynamic inventory

Commit If834e5e60f79a7418cbc1441d2aaf85507ac7bd2 broke support for the
dynamic inventory since Ansible requires different formats for the hosts
value in groups.

This patch corrects the issue and restores the ability to use
tripleo-ansible-inventory as either a static or dynamic inventory
source.

Change-Id: I035bb878508ceab06279cbaf07969aafeb66b9e5
Story: 2001929
(cherry picked from commit 480aeadc1cc23664e4c58edbecfccb5bb1c2ba61)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-17 15:27:33.000000000', 'message': 'Use hostnames in inventory

This patch updates the inventory code to produce an inventory that uses
hostnames as the host alias. Since the hostname may not always be
resolvable, ansible_host is added as a hostvar and set to the host's IP
address.

Using hostnames produces a much more user friendly result in the ansible
output showing task result and play recap.

The anti-pattern of creating one group per host is also removed in favor
of just adding additional hosts under the role named groups. E.g., the
"Controller" group will now contain 3 hosts when deploying 3 controllers
instead of having 3 child groups, where each child group only had 1
host.

hostvars are again used to set specific values on each host in the role
named group.

Change-Id: If834e5e60f79a7418cbc1441d2aaf85507ac7bd2
Closes-Bug: #1752057
(cherry picked from commit 5822ccc62027c5905115120632b4d1622cea7a01)

commit_message:
Use hostnames in inventory

This patch updates the inventory code to produce an inventory that uses
hostnames as the host alias. Since the hostname may not always be
resolvable, ansible_host is added as a hostvar and set to the host's IP
address.

Using hostnames produces a much more user friendly result in the ansible
output showing task result and play recap.

The anti-pattern of creating one group per host is also removed in favor
of just adding additional hosts under the role named groups. E.g., the
"Controller" group will now contain 3 hosts when deploying 3 controllers
instead of having 3 child groups, where each child group only had 1
host.

hostvars are again used to set specific values on each host in the role
named group.

Change-Id: If834e5e60f79a7418cbc1441d2aaf85507ac7bd2
Closes-Bug: #1752057
(cherry picked from commit 5822ccc62027c5905115120632b4d1622cea7a01)

commit_message:
Lock net-telnet gem to 0.1.1

net-telnet just released 0.2.0 which requires
ruby >= 2.3.0 which CentOS does not provide.

This locks that gem to 0.1.1 which was used before.
See the following issue [1].

[1] https://github.com/ruby/net-telnet/issues/14

Change-Id: I538acd4128d93d10fec15564bbc26eb7994303d0
(cherry picked from commit 3693fbbfa8566d8cc39d8d69a899e7b2a79002cf)

[{'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-07-15 23:45:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2018-07-16 12:56:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thanks for volumteering!

It will be great to get the functional tests running, and I was waiting for that to happen to move the tests from experimental to the default queues.  Sometimes its faster to get a result from the experimental queue.

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: Iee69eae0043a401eb355a1fcb957879904882e85

messages:
[{'account_id': 20936, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-07-20 13:05:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-07-20 15:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20936, 'date': '2018-07-20 15:18:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@pkomarov can you help me in testing this on OSP10 before merging?'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-23 02:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-23 02:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 28751, 'date': '2018-07-25 11:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> @pkomarov can you help me in testing this on OSP10 before merging?

Hi, I commited the same change :(. If it helps I tested it in a customer and it works. The only thing that you will have to change is in apply.yml line 252 change domain={{ overcloud_domain }} for domain="{{ overcloud_domain }}".

I do not know if there is a better way to report that or fix it myself. This is my firts commit to osp so I am a bit newbie'}, {'account_id': 20936, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:02:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Hi, I commited the same change :(. If it helps I tested it in a
 > customer and it works. The only thing that you will have to change
 > is in apply.yml line 252 change domain={{ overcloud_domain }} for
 > domain="{{ overcloud_domain }}".
 > I do not know if there is a better way to report that or fix it
 > myself. This is my firts commit to osp so I am a bit newbie

One question: why the quotation marks? it's a domain name, it will never have spaces in it or special chars, so why?'}, {'account_id': 28751, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > Hi, I commited the same change :(. If it helps I tested it in a
 > > customer and it works. The only thing that you will have to
 > change
 > > is in apply.yml line 252 change domain={{ overcloud_domain }} for
 > > domain="{{ overcloud_domain }}".
 > > I do not know if there is a better way to report that or fix it
 > > myself. This is my firts commit to osp so I am a bit newbie
 > 
 > One question: why the quotation marks? it's a domain name, it will
 > never have spaces in it or special chars, so why?

Hi, it is an ansible variable.

 > > Hi, I commited the same change :(. If it helps I tested it in a
 > > customer and it works. The only thing that you will have to
 > change
 > > is in apply.yml line 252 change domain={{ overcloud_domain }} for
 > > domain="{{ overcloud_domain }}".
 > > I do not know if there is a better way to report that or fix it
 > > myself. This is my firts commit to osp so I am a bit newbie
 > 
 > One question: why the quotation marks? it's a domain name, it will
 > never have spaces in it or special chars, so why?

It is an ansible variable. When I run it first time without quotation marks it failed. I had to include to make it work. Maybe the ansible version, I do not know.'}, {'account_id': 27978, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20936, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[...]
 > It is an ansible variable. When I run it first time without
 > quotation marks it failed. I had to include to make it work. Maybe
 > the ansible version, I do not know.

True, but as you can see around the task list, in all the multiple line shell commands we don't need the ".'}, {'account_id': 28751, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> [...]
 > > It is an ansible variable. When I run it first time without
 > > quotation marks it failed. I had to include to make it work.
 > Maybe
 > > the ansible version, I do not know.
 > 
 > True, but as you can see around the task list, in all the multiple
 > line shell commands we don't need the ".

I suppose that you meant 288 and 292 lines. " are used but in that lines they quoted all command.

My intention is to help due to the code is tested. Without the " I had an error, maybe for the ansible version I do not know because If I am not wrong in last ansible versions " are not needed any longer. So if you test the code and get the same error that myself just to clarify that using " worked for me.'}, {'account_id': 20936, 'date': '2018-07-25 16:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

[...]
 > I suppose that you meant 288 and 292 lines. " are used but in that
 > lines they quoted all command.
 > My intention is to help due to the code is tested. Without the " I
 > had an error, maybe for the ansible version I do not know because
 > If I am not wrong in last ansible versions " are not needed any
 > longer. So if you test the code and get the same error that myself
 > just to clarify that using " worked for me.

Sure, I totally understand, and thanks for the contribution.
We can think about an additional review to correct such thing (because as I wrote it concerns also other portion of code).
In all the tests we made for this review that kind of error was never hit, so I'll merge it, but nothing prevents us to go back on this once we have a clear reproducer.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 13:03:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix hard-coded domain in instance HA role

This commit sets a default value of "localdomain" for the domain
parameter related to the overcloud.
This is used inside the role while configuring nova-compute-checkevacuate
resource and the fence-nova STONITH device. In this way, the user will
be able to override the default by passing the overcloud_domain
parameter in the command line.

Fixes-Bug: #1782752
Change-Id: Ib76523a08e43b8d9f604e9fb2544017c9800d8a9
'}]
commit_message:
Fix hard-coded domain in instance HA role

This commit sets a default value of "localdomain" for the domain
parameter related to the overcloud.
This is used inside the role while configuring nova-compute-checkevacuate
resource and the fence-nova STONITH device. In this way, the user will
be able to override the default by passing the overcloud_domain
parameter in the command line.

Fixes-Bug: #1782752
Change-Id: Ib76523a08e43b8d9f604e9fb2544017c9800d8a9

messages: [{'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2018-07-25 12:58:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-25 13:08:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 12:58:36.000000000', 'message': 'Lock net-telnet gem to 0.1.1

net-telnet just released 0.2.0 which requires
ruby >= 2.3.0 which CentOS does not provide.

This locks that gem to 0.1.1 which was used before.
See the following issue [1].

[1] https://github.com/ruby/net-telnet/issues/14

Change-Id: I538acd4128d93d10fec15564bbc26eb7994303d0
(cherry picked from commit 3693fbbfa8566d8cc39d8d69a899e7b2a79002cf)
'}]
commit_message:
Lock net-telnet gem to 0.1.1

net-telnet just released 0.2.0 which requires
ruby >= 2.3.0 which CentOS does not provide.

This locks that gem to 0.1.1 which was used before.
See the following issue [1].

[1] https://github.com/ruby/net-telnet/issues/14

Change-Id: I538acd4128d93d10fec15564bbc26eb7994303d0
(cherry picked from commit 3693fbbfa8566d8cc39d8d69a899e7b2a79002cf)

commit_message:
neutron-server-opendaylight: install ceilometer pip explicitly

During build pip is not able to install ceilometer dependency so build
fails. But if given as a thing to "pip install" then build succeds.

Probably not best solution.

Closes-bug #1764621

Change-Id: I3a7a9f17781a70b3f596119ca40122ce4ff3999c

subject: Configure notifications to be unversioned
messages: [{'account_id': 8992, 'date': '2018-07-20 19:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-07-25 15:45:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-20 19:00:52.000000000', 'message': 'Configure notifications to be unversioned

Beginning in the Pike release, Nova started sending both versioned
and unversioned notifications. The verioned notification queues do
not have any consumers so this causes some queues to fill up until
either the messages expire or they are flushed. This changes the
nova configuration to only send unversioned (legacy) notifications.

Change-Id: Idca18960542b7d7710b8f6c4ee1c579603b0e08b
Related-bug: #1665449
'}]
commit_message:
Configure notifications to be unversioned

Beginning in the Pike release, Nova started sending both versioned
and unversioned notifications. The verioned notification queues do
not have any consumers so this causes some queues to fill up until
either the messages expire or they are flushed. This changes the
nova configuration to only send unversioned (legacy) notifications.

Change-Id: Idca18960542b7d7710b8f6c4ee1c579603b0e08b
Related-bug: #1665449

messages: [{'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-28 09:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-28 12:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\ncharm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-07-25 15:36:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 09:45:07.000000000', 'message': 'Support for neutron context without credentials

If the compute node is deployed in a cell it will get service
credentials via a direct relationship with keystone and not
from a nova-cloud-controller relation. This change adds support
for having a complete CloudComputeContext without having
service credentials.

Change-Id: Ie2160a08e431a2c681bda84dfe32a4fa11f2aaae
'}]
commit_message:
Support for neutron context without credentials

If the compute node is deployed in a cell it will get service
credentials via a direct relationship with keystone and not
from a nova-cloud-controller relation. This change adds support
for having a complete CloudComputeContext without having
service credentials.

Change-Id: Ie2160a08e431a2c681bda84dfe32a4fa11f2aaae

subject: Add py36 testenv
messages: [{'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-07-24 11:46:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-07-25 14:53:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-24 11:46:59.000000000', 'message': "Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: I5f46c652dbc988991b2d506d66a985de7e5af8c9
"}]
commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: I5f46c652dbc988991b2d506d66a985de7e5af8c9

[{'created': '2018-07-20 19:01:03.000000000', 'message': 'Configure notifications to be unversioned

Beginning in the Pike release, Nova started sending both versioned
and unversioned notifications. The verioned notification queues do
not have any consumers so this causes some queues to fill up until
either the messages expire or they are flushed. This changes the
nova configuration to only send unversioned (legacy) notifications.

Change-Id: Ibaef9dfd75cf2ce6c20d92746b3cf7b37bac24b9
Related-bug: #1665449
'}]
commit_message:
Configure notifications to be unversioned

Beginning in the Pike release, Nova started sending both versioned
and unversioned notifications. The verioned notification queues do
not have any consumers so this causes some queues to fill up until
either the messages expire or they are flushed. This changes the
nova configuration to only send unversioned (legacy) notifications.

Change-Id: Ibaef9dfd75cf2ce6c20d92746b3cf7b37bac24b9
Related-bug: #1665449

commit_message:
Unversioned endpoint recommendation

APIv2 is reaching stability. People will want to use it. It's best,
although not actually required, if deployers put an unversioned
endpoint for Sahara in the service catalog.

Change-Id: I0256c2002c6c25969fd23cc6f6d3b11c3e577646

[{'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-07-19 18:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-07-19 18:16:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-07-19 21:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-07-20 05:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-07-23 13:17:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-07-23 18:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-07-24 11:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-07-24 11:38:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-07-25 14:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add netloc and version check for version discovery

If the url netloc in the catalog and service's response
are not the same, we should choose the catalog's and
add the version info to it if needed.

Conflict and change in test is caused by I93ee971125bc0c7a497e1fb839df38ebd38340e1,
I07a602a05f896d7cc70120bd89424e3c553baf9f and Icf855d7892335b093c1083cd0106946d8911010d

Change-Id: If78d368bd505156a5416bb9cbfaf988204925c79
Closes-bug: #1733052
(cherry picked from commit 323f4e4bc4710d42e493eb56e40ba139a84d67b3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-25 12:58:02.000000000', 'message': 'Lock net-telnet gem to 0.1.1

net-telnet just released 0.2.0 which requires
ruby >= 2.3.0 which CentOS does not provide.

This locks that gem to 0.1.1 which was used before.
See the following issue [1].

[1] https://github.com/ruby/net-telnet/issues/14

Change-Id: I538acd4128d93d10fec15564bbc26eb7994303d0
'}]
commit_message:
Lock net-telnet gem to 0.1.1

net-telnet just released 0.2.0 which requires
ruby >= 2.3.0 which CentOS does not provide.

This locks that gem to 0.1.1 which was used before.
See the following issue [1].

[1] https://github.com/ruby/net-telnet/issues/14

Change-Id: I538acd4128d93d10fec15564bbc26eb7994303d0

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 21:37:36.000000000', 'message': 'Dynamically generate tags for oslo_log fluentd formatter

This proposes changing the tags added to the openstack logs
gathered by the fluentd handler from `openstack.<service>` to
`Namespace.Release` to account for multiple instances of openstack
services being deployed into different namespaces. This allows for
fine tuning the search queries in elasticsearch/kibana to target
specific service deployments in specific namespaces

Change-Id: Ia12dceb4089e107e15d8e30c92c91f350dc31318
'}, {'created': '2018-07-02 14:06:43.000000000', 'message': 'Dynamically generate tags for oslo_log fluentd formatter

This proposes changing the tags added to the openstack logs

commit_message:
Dynamically generate tags for oslo_log fluentd formatter

This proposes changing the tags added to the openstack logs
gathered by the fluentd handler from `openstack.<service>` to
`Namespace.Release` to account for multiple instances of openstack
services being deployed into different namespaces. This allows for
fine tuning the search queries in elasticsearch/kibana to target
specific service deployments in specific namespaces

Change-Id: Ia12dceb4089e107e15d8e30c92c91f350dc31318

[{'created': '2018-07-13 14:46:16.000000000', 'message': 'Ceph-Mon/Ceph-OSD: Update default fluentbit configuration

As of 0.12.14, fluentbit exposes a flag for setting the db_sync
behavior for writing the location of the tail input to its sqlite
database. The default setting is Full, which introduces additional
synchronizations before and after a transaction. This has the
potential to negatively affect disk performance with the extra
synchronizations. This moves the setting in the chart to Normal,
which performs fewer synchronizations and still maintains a high
level of safety with status writes

Change-Id: I5de8ee40162a50e1ff3395d0e302974b77dd5f9c
'}]
commit_message:
Ceph-Mon/Ceph-OSD: Update default fluentbit configuration

As of 0.12.14, fluentbit exposes a flag for setting the db_sync
behavior for writing the location of the tail input to its sqlite
database. The default setting is Full, which introduces additional
synchronizations before and after a transaction. This has the
potential to negatively affect disk performance with the extra
synchronizations. This moves the setting in the chart to Normal,
which performs fewer synchronizations and still maintains a high
level of safety with status writes

Change-Id: I5de8ee40162a50e1ff3395d0e302974b77dd5f9c

commit_message:
Add missing argument in overrides yaml

This patch modifies two points:
1. Add OSH_EXTRA_HELM_ARGS in tempest script.
2. When running pike or ocata release with overrides,
   some docker image are missing.

Change-Id: I5fc7c059be009f4298a8dc2880a214137a65fc87
